mfmatr.title: SERVICE BULLETIN LIST
mfmatr.para: The Service Bulletins given in this list are applicable to the PW617F-E engine family. This list contains four columns which are:
- The P&WC SB No. The SB are given in sequence of P&WC SB number
- The ATA SB No. The ATA bulletin prefix PW617F-E is not given into the list.
- The Rev. No. which is the revision number of the SB.

- The Incorporation Status. The term INCORPORATED in this column shows that the SB is incorporated in the manual. The term NO EFFECT in this column shows that no change to the manual was necessary for that SB number. The term NOT USED in this column shows that there is no SB document available at the time the manual SB list was revised.

prcitem.title: General
prcitem.para: This Overhaul Manual is published by Pratt and Whitney Canada (P&WC). It contains the approved and recommended procedures necessary for the full overhaul of the PW617F-E (BS1209) engine.

All process parameters specified in this manual must be adhered to. This manual is the standard document for the procedures given. It is not permitted to change the procedures or do them differently without written approval from Pratt & Whitney Canada. The data in this manual is the result of field experience and of tests done on engines operated in a range of conditions. These procedures will permit you to get the best possible engine performance with the minimum unscheduled maintenance.

Please use the RSVP Customer Feedback Sheet to tell us about any errors or problems you find in this Overhaul Manual. The Technical Publications Department will welcome any suggestions for modification or improvement to these instructions which will increase their usefulness.
You can use an electronic on-line RSVP sheet at www.pwc.ca.
This Overhaul Manual will be revised as necessary to include new approved data.

prcitem.title: Manual Format
prcitem.para: This manual is prepared per ATA iSpec 2200, which is prepared by the Air Transportation Association of America.

This manual is written in Simplified English (SE) per the AECMA Simplified English document, Change No. 5 (No. PSC85-16598), which is prepared by the Association Européenne des Constructeurs de Matériel Aérospatial. You can get this document from the Association Europeene des Constructeurs de Materiel Aerospatial at the address that follows:

The ATA numbers (Chapter/Section/Unit) used in this manual agree with those used in the Illustrated Parts Catalog (IPC). The How to Use section of this manual shows all details on how ATA numbers have been given and it shows you how to use this manual.

prcitem.title: Customer Support Services
prcitem.para: Customer-support Service representatives know about the latest maintenance procedures because they collect data from operators and service center personnel. They are available to analyze any problem. Write to the address which follows, or call the Customer Help Desk, for necessary aid and/or AOG support.

prcitem.title: Supplementary Publications
prcitem.para: The publications which follow are also necessary for correct maintenance or overhaul of the engine:
PW617F-E Airworthiness Limitations Manual (P/N 3072699):
This manual contains the service life limits for rotating components which are necessary to keep the engine certificate valid.
PW617F-E Line Maintenance Manual (P/N 3072696):
This manual contains the approved on-wing removal and installation procedures of external components and engine accessories.
PW617F-E Engine Maintenance Manual (P/N 3072162):

This manual contains approved procedures for removal and installation procedures of external components and engine accessories and Heavy Maintenance (HSI), repair and removals considered beyond the normal capabilities of the average line maintenance shop. The scope includes the removal and installation of engine internal components and limited repair to the hot section area.
Cleaning, Inspection and Repair Manual (CIR) (P/N 3056631):
This manual contains all the approved cleaning, inspection and repair procedures for the engine components.
Illustrated Parts Catalog (IPC) (P/N 3072164):

This manual tells about available parts and it contains a full list of them. It also has illustrations to show how the parts are related. The IPC is divided in the same form as the Engine Maintenance Manual.
Service Bulletins:

The engine Service Bulletins (SB) contain data or instructions which are used to make a modification to engines or parts to make them agree with the latest configuration. Service bulletins contain data which causes a change in the part form, fit or function. The service bulletins have numbers in sequence per ATA-100. They have a PW600 prefix (eg: PW600-72-66000), which shows that they are applicable to the PW617F-E turbofan engine family. References to service bulletins in this manual are given with the P&WC in-house SB numbers (eg: SB66000) which is the last element of the ATA number. Refer to the service bulletin list at the front of this Overhaul Manual for the full list of SBs included in this Overhaul Manual. The service bulletins are available as a set for the PW617F-E engine (P/N ).
Spare Parts Bulletins:

The Spare Parts Bulletins (SPB) contain data for new part numbers given to new parts when optional part numbers are available or new parts are interchangeable with the parts in the configuration before or repair parts are added to the IPC. The spare parts bulletins have numbers with a PW600 (eg: PW600 SPB No. 1), which shows that they are applicable to the PW600 turbofan engine family. Refer to the SPB list at the front of this Overhaul Manual for the full list of SPBs included in this Overhaul Manual.

prcitem.title: Component Maintenance Manuals (CMM) (P&WC)
prcitem.para: These manuals contain the maintenance and overhaul instructions and the illustrated parts list for the accessories supplied by Pratt & Whitney Canada.

There are two types of CMMs; the full CMM and the abbreviated CMM. The full CMM is used when you do a complete overhaul (disassembly, cleaning, inspection, repair, assembly, testing and fault isolation) of an accessory. The abbreviated CMM is used only when a check or a test is necessary on an accessory that you cannot repair.
The CMMs shown in Table are available from Pratt & Whitney Canada.

table.title: List of P&WC Component Maintenance Manuals

prcitem.title: Component Maintenance Manuals (CMM) (Supplier)
prcitem.para: These manuals contain the maintenance and overhaul instructions and the illustrated parts list for the accessories supplied by different suppliers. After initial distribution to customers, you can make an order for a CMM directly from the applicable supplier. When you make such an order, please write the part number of the component for which the CMM is necessary. Table 2 gives a list of all the CMMs which are available from suppliers.

note.para: If there are two or more possible CMMs for one accessory, refer to the IPC for the part number of the applicable CMM.

prcitem.title: Tool Service Bulletin Set (TSB) (P/N 3070908)
prcitem.para: Tool service bulletins are used to make a modification to special tools. The bulletin gives the tool part number on which the modification is necessary. The TSBs have numbers with a PW600 prefix (eg: PW600-0001), which shows that they are applicable to the PW600 turbofan engine family.

prcitem.title: Standard Practices Manual (SPM) (P/N 585005)
prcitem.para: This manual contains approved and recommended standard practices and instructions frequently used for different engines made by Pratt & Whitney.

prcitem.title: P&WC Consumable Materials List (CML) (P/N 3043340)
prcitem.para: This list contains data about consumable materials used in this Overhaul Manual. All consumable materials have a different number. In this Overhaul Manual, where there is a reference to a consumable material, the material name is followed by the item number in parentheses (eg: engine oil (PWC03-001)). Unless differently specified, you can use the alternative material given in the PWC CML which is shown by letter suffix (eg: PWC03-001A). If you must use the basic item number material, an asterisk is shown at the end of the number (eg: PWC03-001*).

Refer to the PWC CML for more data on that consumable material. The PWCXX-YYY item numbers are intended for internal use by P&WC. The numbers give a cross reference between the CML and other P&WC publications. When you make an order for a product, use the trade names, the specifications and the standards of the consumable material listed in the CML as follows:

prcitem.title: Data Reduction Program Manual (P/N 30P10974)
prcitem.para: This manual contains data about the program which is used to change the test cell indication to standard day conditions.

prcitem.title: Special Instructions (SI)
prcitem.para: The data contained in the Special Instructions are of the same type as the data in SBs or in the Overhaul Manual. The SI data is specially prepared for some operators and it is not supplied to all operators. The SIs are identified by a number (eg: P&WC: 21-89 is the 21st SI of 1989).

prcitem.title: Service Information Letter (SIL)
prcitem.para: The data in an SIL is specific to an engine model. There are two types of SIL; the general type (eg: GEN-20058) and the specific type (eg: SIL No. PW-182). The life of an SIL is approximately one year. Usually, the data contained in the SIL will be included in an SB or in the Overhaul Manual.

prcitem.title: Safety
prcitem.para: This Overhaul Manual contains procedures that use chemicals, solvents, paints and other available material. You must read the material safety data sheets (Occupational Safety and Health Act (OSHA) Form 20 or equivalent) before you use these materials. Some materials can be dangerous. The data sheets are available from the manufacturers or the suppliers of these materials.

prcitem.title: Types of Maintenance
prcitem.para: The data contained in this manual is for three types of maintenance.

prcitem.title: Heavy Maintenance
prcitem.para: This type of maintenance includes work done on an engine that is removed from the aircraft and is disassembled to its large assemblies or modules to get access to damaged parts. A check of the modules or large assemblies that are not damaged is necessary. Damaged parts are repaired or replaced and the engine is reassembled. Heavy maintenance is usually pro-active action which is done to keep the engine in an optimum condition (eg: HSI or life item replacement). Heavy maintenance is done in the field or in a service center.

prcitem.title: Engine Repair
prcitem.para: This type of maintenance includes repairs done to an engine that is removed from the aircraft and for which you must disassemble a large assembly or module to the smallest subassemblies. A full visual inspection is necessary for all disassembled parts and all removed subassemblies. A check of the remaining modules and large assemblies that are not disassembled is necessary. Defective subassemblies are repaired or replaced and the engine is reassembled. An engine repair is usually a reactive action done to correct a condition that makes the engine unserviceable (eg: unscheduled inspection because of unusual conditions). Engine repairs are usually done in a service center.

prcitem.title: Overhaul
prcitem.para: This type of maintenance includes work done on an engine or large assembly or module that is removed from the aircraft and is fully disassembled to its detail parts. A full inspection of all parts is necessary. The defective parts are repaired or replaced and the engine is reassembled. A full test of the engine is necessary to make sure that its performance is satisfactory. Overhauls are only done in a service center.

prcitem.title: Weights and Measures
prcitem.para: The weight and measure units are given in Imperial and SI (System International metric system) units. The Imperial units are given first followed by the equivalent SI units in parentheses. If there is a difference between the value of an Imperial unit and that value converted to an SI unit, always use the Imperial value.

prcitem.title: General
prcitem.para: This section gives the Overhaul Manual organization for the applicable PW600 Engine. It also gives some guidelines to help the user to find data. This manual gives specific data for the engine only. The engine includes the engine-driven accessories as supplied as initial equipment by the engine manufacturer, but it does not include the accessories supplied by the airframe manufacturer. Engine-supplied accessory data is included in each Component Maintenance Manual (CMM) as given in the Introduction of this manual.

prcitem.title: Organization of Data
prcitem.para: The manual is divided into two parts; the Airworthiness Limitations (AWL) Section and Chapter 72 - Engine. Refer to Manual Numbering System (Para. 5.) for more data on how the Chapter/Section/Subject numbering system is used in this manual.

prcitem.title: Airworthiness Limitations (AWL) Section
prcitem.para: This section refers to the applicable Airworthiness Limitations Manual where you will find the rotor component cyclic life limits.

prcitem.title: Manual Numbering System
prcitem.para: The manual numbering system uses the following rules for the presentation of the documentation as follows:

A three-element Chapter/Section/Subject number is given to each engine section and to each important part in the engine. This number is in the lower right corner of each page adjacent to the page number. These numbers are given per the Air Transport Association (ATA) Specification 100. The Chapter/Section/Subject numbers do not change with the part progression related to SB changes. For example, if there are many SBs that change the compressor case, it will always keep the same Chapter/Section/Subject number (72-33-01).
The first element of the number identifies the Chapter. This manual contains data applicable to Chapter 72.

The second element identifies the engine section. Refer to Para. 3. for the different sections in Chapter 72. In the Engine General chapters (72-00-XX), the engine section identifiers are used in the third element. These numbers identify data related to a left and right disassembler/assembler.

unlitem.para: 72-00-01 Engine General - Right Side Engine Assembler
72-00-02 Engine General - Left Side Engine Assembler

prcitem.para: The third element identifies important parts or units of the specific engine section. For example, 72-33-01 would be as follows

unlitem.para: X3, Subsection identifier - Compressor Case Assembly
01, Subject (important part or unit) - Tower Shaft

prcitem.title: Page Footing
prcitem.para: Each manual page has a different page footing identifier (Ref. Fig. ).

graphic.title: Page Footing

prcitem.para: The right page footing contains the Chapter/Section/Subject number, function title, page block number and page revision date. The configuration number, if applicable, follows the function title.
The left page footing contains the engine model effectivity and, if applicable, the Service Bulletin number.

prcitem.title: Engine Model Effectivity
prcitem.para: The engine model effectivity for this manual, given by the model(s) and related Build Specification(s), is given on the title page.
Manual sections applicable to all of the models given on the title page have an effectivity in the page footing that reads:
Manual sections applicable to a specific engine model and Build Specification are identified with an effectivity in the page footing as follows:

prcitem.title: Function Titles and Page Block Numbers
prcitem.para: The separation of data in this manual is identified by a function title and a page block number. These identifiers are located at the lower right area of each page. Function titles are also printed in the heading on each page. Most functional sections are also divided (Inspection/Check-00, Inspection/Check-01, etc.) for specific tasks in a page block.
Function titles and the related page block numbers are divided as follows:
DESCRIPTION AND OPERATION, pages 1 - 99 : No description and operation details is given in this manual, instead it directs you to the applicable Maintenance Manual for the information.

SPECIAL PROCEDURES, pages 201 - 299: This page block contains procedures that are necessary as a result of other maintenance procedures and that are not included in other functional page blocks. Procedures in this page block are referenced to other functional sections.
DISASSEMBLY, pages 501 - 599: This page block gives the procedures for disassembly of an engine section into its detail parts and units.

The procedures are for partial or full disassembly of an engine section. Disassembly does not include separation of riveted or equivalent subassemblies. If more disassembly is necessary, data will be in the specific repair of the part.
CLEANING, pages 601 - 699: This page block gives procedures for engine gaspath cleaning and specific cleaning of the detail parts in an engine section.

INSPECTION/CHECK, pages 801 - 899: This page block gives the full inspection and check procedures which are used to find the serviceability of a part or unit. The data in this function includes fits and clearances, borescope inspection, airflow checks, oil flow checks, leak checks, dimensional inspection, visual inspection, and non-destructive inspection (fluorescent penetrant, magnetic particle, etc.).
REPAIR, pages 901 - 999: This page block gives the full repair procedures approved for part or unit refurbishment. Each repair procedure contains references to specific part numbers.
ASSEMBLY, pages 1001 - 1099: This page block gives the procedures for assembly of the detail parts into an engine section or subsection (subassembly).
SERVICING, pages 1101 - 1199: This page block gives the procedures for regular servicing of engine systems. This function includes draining and filling of the engine oil system.

STORAGE, pages 1201 - 1299: This page block gives the procedures for preservation of the engine during storage and procedures for depreservation after storage. Procedures to remove and install the engine, turbomachinery or gearbox, from and into shipping containers, are also included in this page block.
TESTING, pages 1301 - 1399: This page block gives the procedures and limits to make sure that the performance of the engine is fully serviceable after you do other maintenance functions

prcitem.title: Data Locating Guidelines
prcitem.para: You can find data for an assembled engine as follows:
Find the function of the necessary data.
Find the functional page block in the Table of Contents of the 72-00-00 Engine General section.
You can find specific data in the manual in the same sequence as shown in the Table of Contents.
You can find specific data for an engine part as follows:
If you know the part name and/or general engine location, refer to the Chapter/Section/Subject Numbering List (Para. 12.) and related illustrations and find the ATA number given to the part.

If you are not sure of the part name but you know the part number, find the Chapter/Section/Subject number (ATA number) in the IPC detailed parts list. The ATA number is found in parenthesis below the part number.
Find the tab separator related to the Chapter/Section number found in the steps above.
Find the part in the How to Use section or in the Table of Contents for that manual section. The Table of Contents is in numerical sequence by ATA number.
Page block numbers and function titles for the subject part are in numerical sequence in the Table of Contents and in the same sequence in the manual.

If inspection data is necessary for the part, refer to the part number index in the Inspection/Check-00 for the ATA number of the part. The index gives all inspection procedures that are applicable for the specific part number.

If repair data is necessary for the part, refer to the part number index in the Repair-00 for the ATA number of the part. The index gives all repair procedures that are applicable for the specific part number.

prcitem.title: Task Numbering System
prcitem.para: The structure of this manual is controlled by the Air Transport Association (ATA) Specification No. 100, Rev. 34. It uses the Jet Engine Maintenance Task Oriented Support System (JEMTOSS) which has task and subtask numbers for text, illustrations and tables. The system permits this manual to adapt to the different electronic or manual systems of the users (Ref. Fig. )

graphic.title: Task/Subtask Numbering System

prcitem.para: The task numbering system permits selection of data or cross-references because each task or subtask number is different. The task numbers give an accurate point of reference that will not change with revisions to pages or paragraph numbers.

Each operation specified in this manual has a task number which is controlled by ATA Specification 100 numbering system and the function of the data. The task number contains five (or six) elements. The first three of these elements are the ATA number and they give the Chapter/Section/Subject number.

The fourth element identifies the function (assembly, inspection, repair, test, etc.). Refer to Table 1 for specific fourth element function identification. The fifth element gives a different identification for each task/subtask in the function. Task identifiers, given in sequence, start at 801 and subtask identifiers start at 001. A sixth element is given, if necessary, to identify the differences in configuration or the differences of method from the initial task.

Subtask numbers are also given to steps in the task. This permits identification of changes in functions, work stations or area of the part in a task. For example, a repair can include stripping, pre-machining, plating, final-machining and heat treatment procedures. Subtask numbers are given, as necessary, to each text unit to show the function change.

Each SPOP (Service Process Operation Procedure) in the Standard Practices Manual (SPM) has a subtask number. The first three elements are the ATA number of the page block in the SPM. The fourth and fifth elements are given as found above. This subtask number is in parentheses after the reference to the SPOP in procedural text.
When a SPOP or PWA procedure is used for a part in this manual, the first three elements of the SPM task or subtask number are replaced with the ATA number of that part.

The task numbers are included in this manual to help the operator in the management of technical data (Production Management Data Base (PMDB), if the JEMTOSS system is used. The JEMTOSS system does not change the configuration of the technical data in this manual.

prcitem.title: Pre-requisites and Equipment and Materials
prcitem.para: The procedures included in this manual usually start with two paragraphs, Pre-requisites and Equipment and Materials.

prcitem.title: Pre-requisites
prcitem.para: This paragraph gives procedures that you must do before you start the procedure which follows the paragraph. A reference is given only for the last task which is necessary before you do the procedure.

prcitem.title: Equipment and Materials
prcitem.para: This paragraph contains, if applicable, the P&WC special tools, fixtures and equipment, consumable materials. This paragraph does not include tools which are in position (e.g. build stands and fixtures) and the usual tools which are used by mechanics. Consumable materials are identified by an item number and a name. The data for each consumable material is included in the PWC Consumable Material List (CML). This list does not include data about consumables that are included in a SPOP in the Standard Practices Manual (SPM).

prcitem.title: Chapter/Section/Subject Numbering List (ATA numbers)

Numbers which have no names are identified in the list by one of the two terms which follow:

unlitem.para: Unassigned - This term is used for numbers which are intentionally ignored and kept for possible subsequent use.
Not Used - This term is given to numbers in other related engine model programs which are not, at this time, applicable to the engine models specified in this manual.

task.title: Mechanical Fault Isolation Procedures for the Engine

tprereq.title: Pre-requisites
tprereq.para: Do an engine test and use these procedures to find the defects. Refer to 72-00-00, Testing-00 (Task 72-00-00-700-801) .

tprereq.title: General
tprereq.para: These procedures are used to find problems at engine test or as an aid to find problems for an engine received which shows a special fault. Refer to the How To Use section in front of this Engine Manual to understand the breakdown for this engine and to know where to find the data referred to in this section.

To isolate a fault, do a check of all previous information of engine trouble and work that was done on the engine. Do a check on each possible source of trouble by using each of the applicable diagnostic test sequences until the fault is isolated. Systematic checks are essential for an effective fault isolation because they save time and extend the life of the engine.

taskproc.title: List of Mechanical Fault Isolation Procedures
taskproc.para: Refer to the applicable Engine Maintenance Manual for the list of mechanical faults and the probable defect.

task.title: Electronic Engine Control (EEC) Fault Isolation Procedures for the Engine

tprereq.title: Pre-requisites
tprereq.para: Do an engine test and use these procedures to find the defects. Refer to 72-00-00, Testing-00 (Task 72-00-00-700-801) .

tprereq.title: General
tprereq.para: These procedures are used to find problems at engine test or as an aid to find problems for an engine received which shows a special fault. Refer to the How To Use section in front of this Engine Manual to understand the breakdown for this engine and to know where to find the data referred to in this section.

To isolate a fault, do a check of all previous information of engine trouble and work that was done on the engine. Do a check on each possible source of trouble by using each of the applicable diagnostic test sequences until the fault is isolated. Systematic checks are essential for an effective fault isolation because they save time and extend the life of the engine.

taskproc.title: List of EEC Fault Isolation Procedures
taskproc.para: Refer to the applicable Engine Maintenance Manual for the list of EEC fault isolation procedures and the probable defect.

task.title: Removal of the Engine from the Maintenance Stand

l1item.para: This task gives the procedure for removing the engine from the maintenance stand.
Make sure the engine and the maintenance stand are directly beneath the hoist.
Make sure a clear overhead space of at least eight feet (2.44 meters) is available, not including distance from top of engine to hoist hook.
Lock the transport wheels and the gearbox hand wheel on maintenance stand.

subtask.title: Procedure

caution.para: WHEN AN ENGINE IS TO BE REMOVED FROM A MAINTENANCE STAND, MAKE SURE A HOIST OF SUFFICIENT LIFTING CAPACITY AND SAFETY FACTOR IS AVAILABLE.

l1item.para: Install the engine (PWC69262) lifting sling with the (PWC69357) rear bracket on the engine.
Take the weight of the engine on the (PWC69262)lifting sling and make sure the sling is in the horizontal attitude.
Remove the two pins (9 and 10) which attach the compressor case to the (PWC68607)yoke .
Make sure the engine is suspended in the horizontal attitude.
Move the maintenance stand away from the engine.
Remove the four bolts and the four washers which attach the upper (PWC69045)engine mount to the compressor case. Remove the upper (PWC69045) engine mount.
Remove the four bolts and the four washers which attach the lower (PWC69045)engine mount to the compressor case. Remove the (PWC69045) engine mount.
Put the parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

caution.para: DO NOT ALLOW THE ENGINE TO REMAIN SUSPENDED FROM THE HOIST LONGER THAN NECESSARY.

l1item.para: Hoist the engine carefully.

graphic.title: Removal of the Engine from the Maintenance Stand

l1item.para: Install the engine in a shipping container per 72-00-00, Storage-02 (Task 72-00-00-530-802)

title.xref: Removal of the Engine from the Maintenance Stand

task.title: Installation of the Engine on the Maintenance Stand

l1item.para: This task gives the procedure for installing the engine on the maintenance stand.
Make sure a clear overhead space of at least eight feet (2.44 meters) is available, not including distance from top of engine to hoist hook.
Make sure the maintenance stand is directly below the hoist and the engine handling sling.
Lock the transport wheels on the maintenance stand.
If the engine is being installed after removal from the engine shipping container:

l2item.para: Remove the eight bolts and two front shipping brackets installed on the LPC case right and left lower mount pads. Retain the bolts.
Remove the eight bolts, eight washers and eight nuts and the two rear shipping brackets installed on the bypass duct rear flange at the four and eight o'clock positions. Retain the fasteners.
If applicable, remove the four bolts and upper shipping bracket installed on the LPC case upper outboard mount pad.

subtask.title: Procedure

caution.para: DO NOT ALLOW ENGINE TO CONTACT ANY PART OF ENGINE STAND AS IT IS LOWERED INTO POSITION.

l1item.para: Remove the two upper and lower (PWC69045) engine mounts from the (PWC68607) yoke on the maintenance stand.
Install the upper (PWC69045) engine mount on the LP compressor case upper front mount pad as follows:

l2item.para: Lubricate the threads of the four bolts with ( PWC03-001)engine oil.
Install the upper (PWC69045) engine mount with the four washers and the four bolts. Torque the bolts 150 to 170 lb.in. (17.3-19.6 Nm).

l1item.para: Install the lower (PWC69045) engine mount on the LP compressor case lower front mount pad as follows:

l2item.para: Lubricate the threads of the four bolts with ( PWC03-001)engine oil.
Install the lower (PWC69045) engine mount with the four washers and the four bolts. Torque the bolts 150 to 170 lb.in. (17.3-19.6 Nm).

caution.para: MAKE SURE THE MAINTENANCE STAND WHEELS ARE LOCKED.
MAKE SURE THE (PWC68626) ADAPTER AND THE (PWC69045) YOKE ARE IN THE POSITION SHOWN IN RELATION TO THE COMPRESSOR CASE (REF. DETAIL A).

l1item.para: Lower the engine and align the holes in the two upper and lower ( PWC69045)engine mounts with the (PWC68607)yoke .
Install the two pins to secure the engine on the maintenance stand.
Remove the engine handling (PWC69262) sling, (PWC69357) rear bracket and it's attaching hardware from the engine.

graphic.title: Installation of Engine on Maintenance Stand

l1item.para: Remove the engine shipping hardware per 72-00-00, Storage-01 (Task 72-00-00-540-801).

title.xref: Installation of Engine on Maintenance Stand

l1item.para: Refer to the Standard Overhaul Practices in the Standard Practices Manual (SPM, Chapter 70-00) for general removal data.
Items identified on the illustrations indicate the sequence step in the text.
Always use wire gages or taper feeler gages when you measure blade tip clearances.
Handle the bearings per the SPM (Chapter 70-35) and per the Care, Cleaning and handling of Antifriction Bearings Manual P&WC P/N 3040337.

Each bearing assembly is identified by a part number and by a serial number. The serial number is identified by a prefix (eg: SERIAL NUMBER, SER or S/N). This serial number is written on the inner and outer races and on the ball cages where applicable. You must keep these bearings as assemblies as identified by the serial numbers.
P&WC recommends that you use disassembly sheets. You can put these sheets in the engine records. It is possible that you will refer to them again.
The words keywasher, tabwasher and cupwasher are interchangeable. Usually, the word keywasher is used for all types.

During the removal of the fuel system and the oil system parts, examine the condition of the packings. Look for pieces that are damaged or cut from the packings, although this can cause the disassembly and the cleaning of the system.
Unless differently specified, all the threads used in this engine are right-hand threads. You must turn clockwise to tighten the parts and counterclockwise to loosen the parts.
The number of submodules (sections) to remove from the engine is known from the type of work which is necessary. There are two general types of work:

unlitem.para: An engine overhaul or a specified repair, and

l1item.para: The complete disassembly of the engine has two steps.

unlitem.para: The first step is to remove the submodules (sections) from the engine. These procedures are included in the 72-00-00, Removal of the engine components.
The second step is to disassemble the submodules (sections). These procedures are included in the 72-XX-00, Disassembly sections of this Engine Manual.

l1item.para: Refer to 72-00-00 Disassembly-00 for the recommended sequence for the removal of all the submodules (sections) from the engine for an engine overhaul or a specified repair.
For a Hot Section Inspection (HSI), the engine is not fully disassembled. Refer to the applicable PW600 Engine Maintenance Manual for the HSI instructions.

task.title: Removal of the External Tubes and Harness

l1item.para: Refer to the general removal procedures per Removal-00 (Task 72-00-00-000-801).
Refer to 72-00-00 Disassembly-00 (Task 72-00-00-000-802) flowcharts for the sequence of tasks to follow for the complete disassembly of the engine.
Remove the engine from the shipping container per 72-00-00, Special Procedures-01 (Task 72-00-00-500-801).

warning.para: READ THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS BEFORE YOU USE THESE MATERIALS. SOME MATERIALS CAN BE DANGEROUS.

subtask.title: Preparation of Engine for Disassembly

l1item.para: Remove the engine fuel filter element as follows:

l2item.para: Remove the three nuts and the three washers from the fuel filter cover.
Remove the fuel filter cover assembly and the packing from the FOHE. Discard the packing.
Remove the fuel filter element792150pf08011 and the packing792150rp03011 from the FOHE. Discard the packing.
Reinstall the fuel filter cover with the three nuts and the three washers. Tighten the nuts with your hand.

l1item.para: Remove the engine oil filter element as follows:

l2item.para: Remove the three nuts792173an05023 and the three washers792173aw03023 from the cover.
Remove the cover assembly792173pc28021 and the packing792173rp03021 from the oil pump. Discard the packing.
Remove the retaining ring792173ar20021 from the cover.
Remove the oil filter element792150pf08021 and the packing792150rp03021 from the cover. Discard the packing.
Do a visual inspection of the oil filter element for debris. If no debris found, discard the filter element. If debris found, send debris for inspection.
Reinstall the oil filter cover with the four nuts and the four washers. Tighten the nuts with your hand.

warning.para: WEAR EYE PROTECTION WHEN YOU REMOVE LOCKWIRE OR SAFETY CABLE.

l1item.para: Cut and remove all lockwires/safety cable at the start of the removal procedure or when access is possible.
When parts are removed from the engine, they must be put on a parts rack immediately. This will make sure that they are not mixed with other engine parts and prevent possible damage.
Use clean, polyethylene sheets (PWC05-053) or bags (PWC05-054) as covers for all parts.

caution.para: DO NOT PUT CAPS IN THE TUBES. THEY CAN CAUSE A BLOCKAGE OF THE TUBE. ALWAYS PUT THE CAPS ON THE TUBES ENDS.

l1item.para: Put plugs and caps on all the openings to make sure that objects do not fall into the openings.
Look for damage which will not show after the part is cleaned. Identify it and do an inspection before the part is cleaned.
Release all the keywashers and other locking devices before you remove the bolts or the nuts.

Discard the packings, keywashers, oil seals and gaskets when they are removed. But, do not discard the flat keywashers which you do not bend to lock the retaining nuts. Discard bearings during full overhaul. For unscheduled repaired engines, refer to 72-00-00, Inspection/Repair-05 for disposition of the bearings.
Measure and make a record of the thickness of the spacers when they are removed. This can help to make the installation procedures faster if the spacers are changed.
Do a functional check of the T6 system as follows:

l2item.para: Check the insulation resistance as follows:

l3item.para: Connect the Kp and Kn lugs together.
Connect the positive lead of the high voltage insulation tester (ES 893) to the Kp/Kn lugs.
Connect the ground of the tester to the flange of the thermocouple probe.
Raise the voltage to 500 ±10 VDC.
Make sure the resistance is 40 megohms minimum.
Decrease the voltage, remove the tester and separate the lugs.

l2item.para: Check the continuity resistance as follows:

l3item.para: Connect one lead of the multimeter to the Kp lug.
Connect the other lead of the multimeter to the Kn lug.
Make sure there is continuity between the two lugs.

l1item.para: Make sure the engine oil is completely drained from the engine before you remove the engine components.

Remove the chip collector from the valve. Remove the strainers from engine. Remove and discard the packings. Inspect for any particles that might have been collected on the chip collector or on the strainers.

Should particles of metal be found in the fuel and/or oil strainers or chip collector, these could be deposits of steel, tin, aluminum, magnesium, silver, titanium, bronze or cadmium. In some instances, the type of metal may be determined by the color and hardness of the pieces. However, when the particles cannot be positively identified by visual inspection, and knowledge of the exact character of the metal deposits is desired as an aid to troubleshooting, a few simple tests will determine the kind of metal present. To identify unknown metal deposits, refer to the P&WC Standard Practices Manual.

Certain non-corrosive and stainless steels used in the engine are non-magnetic. Should particles that have an appearance of steel texture prove to be non-magnetic when checked with a magnet, continue with the remaining tests for non-ferrous particles. If the particles remain unidentified after these tests, it should be assumed that they are non-magnetic steel.

l1item.para: Remove the bolt773104AB20011 , the nut773104an05211 and the clamp773104RC07011 from the T6 wiring harness.

subtask.title: Removal of the Main Electrical Harness

caution.para: USE THE SOFT JAW PLIERS WHEN YOU DISCONNECT THE ELECTRICAL CONNECTOR. IF YOU DO NOT USE THE SOFT JAW PLIERS, DAMAGE TO THE ELECTRICAL CONNECTOR CAN OCCUR.
SEAL ALL THE OPENINGS AND THE ELECTRICAL CONNECTORS WITH PROTECTIVE CAPS WHEN YOU REMOVE THE MAIN HARNESS. IF UNWANTED MATERIAL FALLS INTO THE OPENINGS THIS CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE ENGINE.

l1item.para: Use (PWC90012)soft jaw pliers and disconnect the connectors P10 and P11 from the FMU.
Use (PWC90012)soft jaw pliers and disconnect P13 connector from the bleed valve actuator (BVA).
Use (PWC90012)soft jaw pliers and disconnect P36 connector from the DCU.

warning.para: USE EYE PROTECTION WHEN YOU CUT THE SAFETY CABLE OR LOCKWIRE. PIECES CAN BREAK OFF AND CAUSE INJURY.

l1item.para: Remove and discard the safety cable. Remove the bolt761104ab20111 from the N1 probe. Carefully remove the N1 probe from the engine. Remove the packing761104rp03011 from the N1 probe. Discard the packing. Seal the opening with a protective cap.
Remove the main harness761104pw17011 from the engine.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the Main Electrical Harness

subtask.title: Removal of the Ignition Cables, the Igniters and the Ignition Exciter

l1item.para: Remove the two nuts742106an05022 and the two clamps742106rc07022 from the engine.
Remove the two nuts742106an05022 and the two clamps742106rc07022 from the engine.
Remove the nut742106an05021 and the clamp742106rc07021 from the cover.
Remove the nut742106an05021 and the clamp742106rc07021 from the engine.
Disconnect the two coupling nuts of the long ignition cable from the igniter and the exciter box. Remove the ignition cable742106pc0102 from the engine.
Remove the two nuts742106an05012 and the two clamps742106rc07012 from the engine.
Remove the nut742106an05011 and the clamp742106rc07011 from the engine.
Disconnect the two coupling nuts of the short ignition cable from the igniter and the exciter box. Remove the ignition cable742106pc01011 from the engine.

caution.para: MAKE SURE THAT YOU DO NOT DROP THE IGNITER. DAMAGE TO THE IGNITER CAN OCCUR.

l1item.para: Remove the two igniters742104pi01012 , the two fairings727170pf01012 and the two grommets727170rg17012 from the engine.
Use the (PWC64173)socket and remove the four nuts741106an05014 , the four bolts741106ab20014 , the four washers741106aw03014 and the ignition exciter741106pe07011 from the engine.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

subtask.title: Removal of the Service Fairing

l1item.para: Remove the four bolts727181ab20014 , the four washers727181aw03014 , the bracket773104RB40011 and the seal retainer727181pr03011 from the service fairing.
Remove the bypass duct seal727173ps06011 from the service fairing.
Remove the two nuts727169an05012 , the two bolts727169ab20012 and the two washers727169aw03012 from the air breather tube bracket.

note.para: Let the service fairing hang on the No.5 bearing oil tubes and the fuel shutoff cable at this time. The service fairing can only be fully removed when the two No.5 bearing oil tubes are removed and the FSO cable is disconnected.

l1item.para: Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the Service Fairing

subtask.title: Removal of the Fuel Shut-off Cable

l1item.para: Remove the nut761106AN05011 and bolt761106AB20011 from the bracket. Remove the clamp761106RC07011 from the FSOV cable.

warning.para: WHEN YOU CUT THE SAFETY CABLE OR LOCKWIRE, USE EYE PROTECTION. PIECES CAN BREAK OFF AND CAUSE INJURY.

l1item.para: Remove the cotter pin761106ap04111 from the FMU shutoff rod. Discard the cotter pin.

Remove and discard safety cable from the nut. Loosen the nut761106DC01011 . Tighten the FSOV cable adjuster sufficiently to disengage the ball end from the FMU shutoff rod. When the ball end is disengaged, remove the FSOV cable adjuster from the FMU bracket. Remove the washer761106DW03011 from the cable.
Slide the FSO cable through the service fairing.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

Remove the air breather tube753130pt17011 from the engine.
Remove the packing753130rp03011 from the rear end of the air breather tube. Discard the packing.
Remove the packing753130rp03011 from the forward end of the air breather tube. Discard the packing.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

l1item.para: Remove the two bolts731130ab20082 from the BVA to FMU fuel tube. Remove the BVA to FMU fuel tube731130pt17081 from the engine. Seal the openings with protective caps.
Remove the packing731130rp03071 from the BVA to FMU fuel tube. Discard the packing.
Remove the packing731130rp03071 from the BVA to FMU fuel tube. Discard the packing.
Remove the two bolts731130ab20072 from the FMU to BVA fuel tube.
Remove the two bolts731130ab20072 from the FMU to BVA fuel tube. Remove the FMU to BVA fuel tube731130pt17071 from the engine. Seal the openings with protective caps.
Remove the packing731130rp03081 from the FMU to BVA fuel tube. Discard the packing.
Remove the packing731130rp03081 from the FMU to BVA fuel tube. Discard the packing.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the BVA/FMU Fuel Tubes

subtask.title: Removal of the No.4 Bearing Oil Pressure Tube

warning.para: USE EYE PROTECTION WHEN YOU CUT THE SAFETY CABLE OR LOCKWIRE. PIECES CAN BREAK OFF AND CAUSE INJURY.

caution.para: USE TWO WRENCHES WHEN YOU DISCONNECT THE TUBES. USE ONE WRENCH TO HOLD THE FITTING AND THE OTHER TO LOOSEN THE COUPLING NUT. DAMAGE CAN OCCUR IF YOU DO NOT USE TWO WRENCHES.

l1item.para: Remove and discard the safety cable from the No.4 bearing oil pressure tube. Disconnect the two coupling nuts and remove the No.4 bearing oil pressure tube792130pt17021 from the engine.
Remove the reducer727178pr02011 from the engine. Remove and discard the packing727167rp03021 from the reducer. Seal the openings with protective caps.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the No.4 Bearing Oil Pressure Tube

subtask.title: Removal of the No.1 to No.3 Bearing Oil Pressure Tube

l1item.para: Remove the nut792130an05051 and the bolt792130ab20051 from the bracket. Remove the two clamps792130rc0715792130rc07092 from the No.1 to No.3 bearing oil pressure tube and the ACOC to FOHE tube.

Remove the two nuts792130an05052 and the two bolts792130ab20052 from the brackets. Remove the four clamps792130rc0705792130rc07094 from the No.1 to No.3 bearing oil pressure tube and the ACOC to FOHE tube.

warning.para: WHEN YOU CUT THE SAFETY CABLE OR LOCKWIRE, USE EYE PROTECTION. PIECES CAN BREAK OFF AND CAUSE INJURY.

caution.para: USE TWO WRENCHES WHEN YOU DISCONNECT THE TUBES. USE ONE WRENCH TO HOLD THE FITTING AND THE OTHER TO LOOSEN THE COUPLING NUT. DAMAGE CAN OCCUR IF YOU DO NOT USE TWO WRENCHES.

l1item.para: Disconnect the coupling nut of the No.1 to No.3 bearing oil pressure tube.

warning.para: USE EYE PROTECTION, WHEN YOU CUT THE SAFETY CABLE OR LOCKWIRE. PIECES CAN BREAK OFF AND CAUSE INJURY.

caution.para: USE TWO WRENCHES WHEN YOU DISCONNECT THE TUBES. USE ONE WRENCH TO HOLD THE FITTING AND THE OTHER TO LOOSEN THE COUPLING NUT. DAMAGE CAN OCCUR IF YOU DO NOT USE TWO WRENCHES.

l1item.para: Remove and discard the safety cable from the coupling nut of the ACOC to FOHE tube. Disconnect the coupling nut of the ACOC to FOHE tube.

caution.para: SEAL ALL THE OPENINGS WITH PROTECTIVE CAPS WHEN YOU REMOVE THE TUBE. IF UNWANTED MATERIAL FALLS INTO THE OPENINGS THIS CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE ENGINE.

l1item.para: Remove the two bolts792130ab20092 from the ACOC to FOHE tube. Remove the ACOC to FOHE tube792130pt17091 from the engine. Remove the packing792130rp03091 from the ACOC to FOHE tube. Discard the packing. Seal the openings with protective caps.

caution.para: SEAL ALL THE OPENINGS WITH PROTECTIVE CAPS WHEN YOU REMOVE THE OIL TUBE. IF UNWANTED MATERIAL FALLS INTO THE OPENINGS THIS CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE ENGINE.

l1item.para: Remove the two bolts792130ab20052 from the No.1 to No.3 bearing oil pressure tube. Remove the No.1 to No.3 bearing oil pressure tube792130pt17051 from the engine. Remove and discard the packing792130rp03051 from the No.1 to No.3 bearing oil pressure tube. Seal the openings with protective caps.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the No.1 to No.3 Bearing Oil Pressure Tube

subtask.title: Removal of the Primary and Secondary Fuel Tubes

warning.para: USE EYE PROTECTION WHEN YOU CUT THE SAFETY CABLE OR LOCKWIRE. PIECES CAN BREAK OFF AND CAUSE INJURY.

l1item.para: Remove and discard the two safety cables from the primary and the secondary fuel tubes. Disconnect the two coupling nuts.

caution.para: USE TWO WRENCHES WHEN YOU DISCONNECT THE TUBES. USE ONE WRENCH TO HOLD THE FITTING AND THE OTHER TO LOOSEN THE COUPLING NUT. DAMAGE CAN OCCUR IF YOU DO NOT USE TWO WRENCHES.

l1item.para: Remove the two bolts731130ab20032 from the primary fuel tube. Remove the primary fuel tube731130pt17031 from the engine. Remove and discard the packing731130rp03031 from the primary fuel tube.

caution.para: USE TWO WRENCHES WHEN YOU DISCONNECT THE TUBES. USE ONE WRENCH TO HOLD THE FITTING AND THE OTHER TO LOOSEN THE COUPLING NUT. DAMAGE CAN OCCUR IF YOU DO NOT USE TWO WRENCHES.

l1item.para: Remove the two bolts731130ab20052 from the secondary fuel tube. Remove the secondary fuel tube731130pt17051 from the engine. Remove and discard the packing731130rp03051 from the secondary fuel tube.

caution.para: SEAL ALL THE OPENINGS WITH PROTECTIVE CAPS WHEN YOU REMOVE THE FUEL TUBES. IF UNWANTED MATERIAL FALLS INTO THE OPENINGS THIS CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TO THE ENGINE.

l1item.para: Seal the openings with protective caps. Put all parts in ( PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the Primary and Secondary Fuel Tubes

subtask.title: Removal of the Air Cooled Oil Cooler

l1item.para: Remove the four nuts792110an05014 and the four washers792110aw03014 from the air cooled oil cooler (ACOC).
Remove the ACOC792110pc24011 from the engine.
Put the ACOC in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or ( PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the Air Cooled Oil Cooler

subtask.title: Removal of the Bleed Valve Actuator

warning.para: WEAR EYE PROTECTION WHEN YOU CUT THE COTTER PIN. PIECES CAN BREAK OFF AND CAUSE EYE INJURY.

l1item.para: Remove and discard the cotter pin753162ap04011 from the bolt. Remove the nut753162an05011 and the bolt753162ab20011 from the rod-end.
Remove the two nuts723360an05212 and the two bolts727160ab20112 from the flange.
Remove the two bolts753106ab20012 , the three washers753106aw03013 , the bracket761104RB40411 and the two nuts753106an05012 from the bleed valve actuator (BVA) support bracket.
Remove the BVA753106pa02011 from the engine.

warning.para: WEAR EYE PROTECTION WHEN YOU CUT THE SAFETY CABLE OR LOCKWIRE. PIECES CAN BREAK OFF AND CAUSE EYE INJURY.

l1item.para: Remove and discard the safety cable from the nut. Remove the nut723457an05111 and the rod end723457pr11031 from the actuator arm.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the Bleed Valve Actuator

subtask.title: Removal of the Document Control Unit (DCU)

l1item.para: Remove the two nuts761105an05012 , the two bolts761105AB20012 , the four washers761105AW03014 and the DCU761105pd01011 from the bracket.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the Document Control Unit (DCU)

subtask.title: Removal of the Turbine Exhaust Case Cowl

l1item.para: Use the (PWC68936)socket and remove the fourteen (14) bolts725560ab200114 , the fourteen (14) washers725560aw032114 and the turbine exhaust case cowl725560pc40011 from the turbine exhaust case.
Remove and discard the fourteen (14) clip nuts725560an050114 from the cowl support brackets.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the Turbine Exhaust Case Cowl

subtask.title: Removal of the Turbine Exhaust Case

l1item.para: Remove the two bolts725561ab20022 and the transducer vibration bracket727193pb40211 .
Remove the twenty-eight (28) bolts725561RB200128 and the fourteen (14) brackets725560ab400114 from the flange.

warning.para: MAKE SURE THAT THE TURBINE EXHAUST CASE IS SUPPORTED BEFORE YOU REMOVE THE BOLTS. IF THE TURBINE EXHAUST CASE FALLS THIS CAN CAUSE INJURIES AND DAMAGE TO THE EXHAUST CASE.

l1item.para: Remove the remaining fifty-nine (59) bolts725561ab200159 from the flange.

caution.para: REMOVE THE TURBINE EXHAUST CASE SLOWLY TO PREVENT DAMAGE TO THE CARBON SEAL.

l1item.para: Install six (PWC32396-200)jacking screws in the six jacking screw holes found in the flange. Equally turn the (PWC32396-200) jacking screws until the flange is released.
Remove the (PWC32396-200) jacking screws from the exhaust case.

caution.para: DO NOT PUT THE TURBINE EXHAUST CASE ON A FLAT SURFACE. THE NO.5 BEARING IS NOT FLUSH WITH THE FLANGE. DAMAGE CAN OCCUR IF YOU PUT THE TURBINE EXHAUST CASE ON A FLAT SURFACE.

l1item.para: Remove the turbine exhaust case725561pc05011 from the engine. Put the turbine exhaust case on an applicable adapter or stand.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the Turbine Exhaust Case

subtask.title: Removal of the Accessory Gearbox

warning.para: WEAR EYE PROTECTION WHEN YOU CUT THE SAFETY CABLE. PIECES CAN BREAK OFF AND CAUSE EYE INJURY.
MAKE SURE THAT THE ACCESSORY GEARBOX IS SUPPORTED BEFORE YOU REMOVE THE BOLTS.

l1item.para: Remove and discard the safety cable. Remove the four bolts723369ab2001723369ab20024 from the accessory gearbox (AGB). Remove the AGB726150ph05011 from the engine. Install the AGB on the applicable stand.
Remove and discard the two dampers726167pd0201726167pd02022 and the packing726167rp03011 from the compressor case.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the Accessory Gearbox

l1item.para: Continue to disassemble the complete engine per 72-00-00, Removal-02 (Task 72-00-00-050-802).
Disassemble the turbine exhaust-case per 72-55-01, Disassembly-01 (Task 72-55-01-040-801).
Disassemble the Bleed Valve Actuator per 72-33-02, Disassembly-01 (Task 72-33-02-050-801).
Disassemble the Accessory Gearbox Externals per 72-61-01, Disassembly-01 (Task 72-61-01-050-801).

task.title: Removal of the Hot Section Components

l1item.para: Refer to the general removal procedures per Removal-00 (Task 72-00-00-000-801).
Refer to 72-00-00 Disassembly-00 (Task 72-00-00-000-802) flowcharts for the sequence of tasks to follow for the complete disassembly of the engine.
Removal of the engine components per 72-00-00, Removal-01 (Task 72-00-00-050-801).

warning.para: READ THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS BEFORE YOU USE THESE MATERIALS. SOME MATERIALS CAN BE DANGEROUS.

subtask.title: Low Pressure Turbine Disk Runout Check

l1item.para: Turn the engine 30 degrees nose down.
Install the (PWC69020)locator on the (PWC69018) clamping tool.

caution.para: MAKE SURE THE MATING FACES OF TOOL AND PART ARE CLEAN AND FREE FROM ANY BURRS OR RAISED MATERIAL.

l1item.para: Install the (PWC69298)gage on the (PWC69018)clamping tool.
Measure and record the axial runout at location shown. Make sure you have a maximum of 0.0015 in. (0.0381 mm).
Measure and record the axial runout high point angle as follows:

l2item.para: The zero degree is located between the Y marks on the LPT disk and the angle is increasing in a counterclockwise direction when looking at the trailing edge.

l1item.para: Remove the (PWC69298)gage from the (PWC69018) clamping tool.
Remove the (PWC69020)locator from the (PWC69018) clamping tool.

graphic.title: Low Pressure Turbine Disk Runout Check

subtask.title: Removal of the Low Pressure Shaft Retaining Bolt

l1item.para: Install the (PWC69122)protector on the LPT and the (PWC66886-8) protector on the impeller.

Install the (PWC68581)uncrimper on the LP shaft retaining bolt725298pb20011 . Align the two levers detail 1( PWC68581) with the two scallops of the LP shaft retaining bolt. Tighten the collar nut detail 6( PWC68581) and unlock the edges of the cup washer725298aw03011 .

note.para: Make sure that the split body detail 13( PWC68581) is correctly engaged to the No.5 bearing seal runner.

l1item.para: Remove the (PWC68581)uncrimper from the LP compressor shaft.
Install the (PWC69125)holder on one of the three aligning anti-rotation lugs of the rear balance rim of the LPT disk.

Use a 3/8 in. square drive extension to hold the anti-rotation ( PWC69125)holder. Loosen and remove the LP shaft retaining bolt. Remove the (PWC69125)holder, the LP shaft retaining bolt and the cup washer. Discard the cup washer.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the Low Pressure Shaft Retaining Bolt

subtask.title: Removal of the No.5 Bearing Seal Runner and Roller Bearing

l1item.para: Install the (PWC69492)puller on the No.5 bearing seal runner.

note.para: Make sure that the split body detail 1( PWC69492) is correctly engaged in the groove of the No.5 bearing seal runner.

l1item.para: Install the (PWC69842)rod, the (PWC71392)adapter and the (PWC89837) cylinder to the (PWC69492) puller.
Connect the (PWC37807)hydraulic pump to the (PWC89837) cylinder. Apply a load of hydraulic pressure to disengage the No.5 bearing seal runner from the LP compressor shaft.
Disconnect the (PWC37807) hydraulic pump. Remove the (PWC89837)cylinder, the ( PWC71392)adapter and the (PWC69842)rod.
Remove the (PWC69492)puller from the engine.
Remove the No.5 bearing seal runner725247pr32011 and the roller bearing725218pb06011 from the (PWC69492)puller. Discard the roller bearing. Remove the ( PWC66886-8)protector from the disk.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the No.5 Bearing Seal Runner and Roller Bearing

subtask.title: Removal of the Low Pressure Turbine Disk Balancing Assembly

note.para: Turn the engine 30 degrees nose down before you remove the LPT disk.

l1item.para: Install the (PWC69140)puller on the LPT disk balancing assembly.

note.para: Make sure that the (PWC69140) puller is correctly engaged in the groove of the LPT disk.

l1item.para: Install the (PWC69842)rod, the (PWC71392)adapter and the (PWC89837) hydraulic cylinder.

warning.para: DO NOT EXCEED 3400 PSI (23442 kPa) OR DAMAGE TO THE PART CAN OCCUR.

l1item.para: Connect the (PWC37807)hydraulic pump to the (PWC89837) hydraulic cylinder. Apply pressure to disengage the LPT disk assembly.
Disconnect the (PWC37807) hydraulic pump. Remove the (PWC89837)hydraulic cylinder, the (PWC71392)adapter, the (PWC69842)rod and the (PWC69140)puller .
Remove the (PWC69122)protector from the LPT disk assembly.
Use the (PWC69125) holder and remove the LPT disk balancing assembly725202pd19011 from the LP compressor shaft.

note.para: Refer to the PW600 CIR Manual P/N 3056631, Chapter 72-52-02 for disassembly instructions of the LPT Disk Assembly.

l1item.para: Remove the spacer725297ps33011 from the LP compressor shaft.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the Low Pressure Turbine Disk Balancing Assembly

subtask.title: Removal of the Low Pressure Turbine Vane Ring

l1item.para: Install the (PWC69009)guide on the LP compressor shaft.
Remove the LPT vane ring725252pv02011 assembly from the LP compressor shaft.

note.para: After the vane is removed, turn the engine to a vertical position.

l1item.para: Remove and discard the fiber packing725274rp03011 from the LPT vane ring.
Remove the (PWC69009)guide from the LP compressor shaft.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the Low Pressure Turbine Vane Ring

subtask.title: High Pressure Turbine Disk Axial Runout Check

l1item.para: Turn the engine 30 degrees nose down.
Install the (PWC69018)clamping tool on the TSC flange.
Install the (PWC69033)runout gage on the (PWC69018) clamping tool.
Measure and record the axial runout of the disk at the backface platform location just below the retaining rivet. The runout must be 0.002 in. (0.05 mm) maximum.

graphic.title: High Pressure Turbine Disk Axial Runout Check

subtask.title: High Pressure Turbine Disk Radial Runout Check

l1item.para: Install the (PWC69163)runout gage on the (PWC69018) clamping tool.
Measure and record the radial runout of the disk at location shown. The runout must be 0.002 in. (0.05 mm) maximum.
Remove the (PWC69163)runout gage from the (PWC69018) clamping tool.

graphic.title: High Pressure Turbine Disk Radial Runout Check

subtask.title: Uncrimping of the Cup Washer

caution.para: MAKE SURE THE LUGS ON THE UNCRIMPER ARE INSTALLED BETWEEN THE NUT AND THE CUPWASHER AT THE CRIMPED LOCATION.

l1item.para: Lubricate the lugs of the (PWC47010) uncrimper with (PWC03-001)engine oil and install on the cupwasher at the crimper location.
Use the (PWC47010)uncrimper and unlock the cupwasher.

note.para: Do not unlock the cupwasher too much. The puller from the Subtask that follows will not fit if the cupwasher is unlocked too much.

l1item.para: Remove the (PWC47010)uncrimper.

graphic.title: Uncrimping of the Cup Washer

subtask.title: Removal of the High Pressure Turbine Retaining Nut

l1item.para:
Apply (PWC06-009) antiseize on the threads of the
puller detail 8( PWC69860) . Install the puller detail 8( PWC69860) and the
nut socket detail 4( PWC69860) on the tie-shaft.

note.para: Loosen the puller detail 8( PWC69860) 1/2 turn.

l1item.para:
Install the pusher detail 1( PWC69860) and the
cylinder detail 6( PWC69860) on the puller detail 8( PWC69860) .
Install the (PWC89837)cylinder and the nut detail 12( PWC69860) and cylinder protector on the (PWC69860)pusher . Connect the (PWC37807)pump to the (PWC89837)cylinder .

warning.para: MAKE SURE THE ALIGNMENT MARKS ON DETAIL 4 AND 6 ARE ALIGNED OR DAMAGE TO THE PART CAN OCCUR.

l1item.para: Apply a load of 200 psi (1378.95 kPa).

caution.para: DO NOT APPLY HYDRAULIC PRESSURE MORE THAN 9400 PSI (64811 kPa) WHEN YOU STRETCH THE TIE-SHAFT DURING THE REMOVAL PROCEDURE.

l1item.para: Apply hydraulic pressure to stretch the tie-shaft. Do not apply more than 9400 psi (64811 kPa). Use the (PWC69507) wrench and loosen 1/2 turn the HPT retaining nut. If you loosen the nut too much, when the pressure is released, the tool may be difficult to remove.

note.para: If the HPT retaining nut does not come loose you can spray the HPT retaining nut with (PWC05-377)penetrating fluid or ( PWC03-001)engine oil and hit the (PWC69507) wrench with a soft hammer.

l1item.para: Release the hydraulic pressure and disconnect the ( PWC37807)pump from the ( PWC89837)cylinder. Remove the (PWC89837)cylinder and the (PWC69860)stretcher from the engine.
Remove the HPT retaining nut725198pn05011 from the engine.
Remove and discard the cupwasher725163pw03011 from the engine.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the High Pressure Turbine Retaining Nut

subtask.title: Removal of the High Pressure Turbine Disk

l1item.para: Install the (PWC69026)rod to the tie-shaft. Install the (PWC69027)puller to the HPT disk balancing assembly.

note.para: Make sure that the (PWC69027) puller is correctly engaged in the groove of the HPT disk balancing assembly.

l1item.para: Install the (PWC89837)cylinder with the (PWC71392) adapter to the (PWC69027) puller and to the (PWC69026) rod.
Connect the (PWC37807)pump to the (PWC89837) cylinder. Apply hydraulic pressure to disengage the HPT disk balancing assembly from the LP compressor shaft.
Disconnect the (PWC37807) pump. Remove the (PWC89837) cylinder and the (PWC71392) adapter from the (PWC69027) puller.
Remove the (PWC69027)puller from the HPT disk balancing assembly. Remove the (PWC69026)rod from the tie-shaft.
Install the (PWC69025)holder on the HP disk.

caution.para: HOLD THE WEIGHT OF THE DISK WHILE YOU REMOVE THE DISK FROM THE ENGINE. THIS IS TO PREVENT POSSIBLE DAMAGE TO THE LP SHAFT.

l1item.para: Remove the HPT disk balancing assembly725102pd19011 from the LP compressor shaft.

note.para: Refer to the PW600 CIR Manual P/N 3056631, Chapter 72-51-02 for disassembly instructions of the HPT Disk Assembly.

l1item.para: Remove the spacer725197ps33011 from the LP compressor shaft.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the High Pressure Turbine Disk

subtask.title: Removal of the High Pressure Turbine Tie-shaft

l1item.para: Install the body Detail 2( PWC69022) on the tieshaft.
Install the (PWC69023)holder on the impeller and shaft assembly.

Install the sleeve Detail 1( PWC69022) and the on the HP turbine tie-shaft. Turn the body detail 2( PWC69022) with a breaker bar to loosen the HP turbine tie-shaft coupling from the LP compressor shaft.
Remove the (PWC69022)socket and the (PWC69023) holder from the HP turbine tie-shaft.
Remove the HP turbine tie-shaft725116ps21011 from the LP compressor shaft.
Remove the (PWC69018)clamping tool from the flange.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the High Pressure Turbine Tie-shaft

subtask.title: Removal of the Turbine Support Case

caution.para: MAKE SURE THAT YOU HOLD THE TURBINE SUPPORT CASE BEFORE YOU TIGHTEN THE JACKING SCREWS. IF THE TURBINE SUPPORT CASE FALLS DAMAGE CAN OCCUR.

l1item.para: Install the six (PWC32396-100)jacking screws into the jacking screw holes. Equally turn the six jacking screws in a cross-torque pattern, until you disengage the turbine support case from the compressor case.
Remove the six (PWC32396-100) jacking screws from the compressor case flange.
Install two (PWC69659)holders on the turbine support case.
Remove the turbine support case725460pc05021 with the air seal.
Remove the two (PWC69659) holders from the turbine support case.
Remove the air seal725162ps06021 from the turbine support case. Discard the air seal.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title: Removal of the Turbine Support Case

subtask.title: Removal of the Oil and P3 Bleed Air Fairings

note.para: The procedure that follows is for the removal of the left oil and P3 bleed air fairing. The removal of the right oil and P3 bleed air fairing is similar.

l1item.para: Remove the nipple727177pn02011 and the packing727167rp03021 from the fairing. Remove and discard the packing from the nipple.

caution.para: MAKE SURE BEFORE YOU REMOVE THE FAIRING THE P3 AIR PASSAGE SPACER OR COOLER ARE SUPPORTED. ATTACH SAFETY CABLE TO THE LOOP TO SECURE THE PARTS FROM DROPPING INTO THE ENGINE.

l1item.para: Remove the two bolts727167ab20312 from the P3 bleed air fairings727167pf01022 .

note.para: Loosen but do not remove the other two bolts from the fairing.

l1item.para: Remove the P3 air cooler727103pc25021 and the gaskets727103rg03012 from front outer bypass duct. Discard the gaskets.
Remove the P3 air passage spacer727197ps33011 and gaskets727197rg03012 from the outer bypass duct. Discard the gaskets.
Remove the two bolts727167ab20312 from the P3 bleed air fairings727167pf01022 .
Remove the two fairings727167pf01022 , the two grommets727167rg17012 and the two gaskets727167rg03012 . Discard the gaskets.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags .

graphic.title: Removal of the Oil and P3 Bleed Air Fairings

subtask.title:
Removal and Disassembly of the Bypass Duct Fuel Fairing (
)

l1item.para: Remove the two bolts727168ab2012727168ab20022 from the fuel fairing.
Use the (PWC69119)puller and remove the bypass duct fuel fairing727168pf01011 from the engine. Remove the gasket727168rg03021 from the fuel fairing. Discard the gasket.
Remove the grommet727167rg17011 from the compressor case.
Install the (PWC68655-2)protector on the fuel inlet tube of the fuel manifold.
Remove the primary fuel reducer tube727179pr02011 and packing 727179rp03011 from the fuel fairing. Discard the packing.
Remove the secondary fuel reducer tube 727179pr02111 and packing727179rp03011 from the fuel fairing. Discard the packing.
Remove the drain valve adapter assembly727192pa03011 and gasket727106rg03011 from the fuel fairing. Discard the gasket.
Disassemble the drain valve as follows:

l2item.para: Remove the retaining ring727106ar20011 from the drain valve adapter.
Remove the drain valve727106pv01011 from the adapter.
Remove the spring727195ps44011 from the adapter.

l1item.para: Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

graphic.title:
Removal and Disassembly of the Bypass Duct Fuel Fairing (
)

subtask.title:
Removal and Disassembly of the Bypass Duct Fuel Fairing (
)

l1item.para: Remove the two bolts727168ab2012727168ab20022 from the fuel fairing.

Disconnect the (PWC37807) hydraulic pump from the (PWC89837)hydraulic cylinder. Remove the (PWC89837)hydraulic cylinder , the (PWC71392)adapter , the (PWC69012)puller and the (PWC69013)pad .

subtask.title: Removal of the High Pressure Compressor Rotor Balancing Assembly

caution.para: BE CAREFUL WHEN YOU REMOVE THE NUTS. DAMAGE CAN OCCUR IF THE NUTS FALL INTO THE BEVEL GEARBOX DRIVE.

l1item.para: Remove the four nuts723360an05014 from the forward side of the HPC rotor balancing assembly. Turn the engine to the nose down position.
Remove the eighteen (18) bolts724150ab200118 from the rear side of the HPC rotor balancing assembly.
Install the (PWC68983)adapter and the (PWC68332) lifter on the HPC rotor balancing assembly. Attach the hoist assembly to the (PWC68332) lifter.

l1item.para: Disengage the HPC rotor balancing assembly from the engine as follows:

l2item.para: Put three (PWC32396-200)jacking screws in the jacking screw holes as shown.
Put three (PWC32396-600)jacking screws in the jacking screw holes as shown.
Equally turn the jacking screws, until the HPC rotor balancing assembly is released.
Remove the six jacking screws from the HPC.

l1item.para:
Install the (PWC68982)rear support on the diffuser case with the three
hand knobs detail 2( PWC68982) .

note.para: The center hand knob must be aligned with the shoulder pin on the diffuser case.

caution.para: DO NOT LIFT THE HPC ROTOR BALANCING ASSEMBLY UNTIL THE BVA ROD IS FULLY INTO THE COMPRESSOR CASE, OTHERWISE DAMAGE CAN OCCUR.

l1item.para: Turn the HPC rotor balancing assembly and put the BVA rod assembly through the HPC case. Slowly remove the HPC rotor balancing assembly from the engine.
Put the HPC rotor balancing assembly on a work bench and disconnect the hoist assembly. Remove the (PWC68332) lifter and the (PWC68983) adapter from the HPC rotor balancing assembly.
Remove the spacer724397ps33031 from the engine.
Put all parts in (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.
