l1item.para: Refer to the Standard Overhaul Practices in the Standard Practices Manual (SPM, Chapter 70-00) for general installation data.

warning.para: WEAR EYE PROTECTION WHEN YOU INSTALL SAFETYWIRE.

l1item.para: Refer to the SPM (Chapter 70-53) for the procedures to install keywashers, safetywire and safety cable.
The words keywasher, tabwasher and cupwasher are interchangeable. Usually, the word keywasher is used for all types.
Before you install the keywashers, do the checks that follow:

unlitem.para: Make sure that there is no surface damage on the face of the nut adjacent to the keywasher.
Make sure that there is no surface damage on the two faces of the keywasher.
Make sure that there is no surface damage on the component where the keywasher is installed.

l1item.para: If not differently specified, use (PWC03-001)engine oil to lubricate all packings, threads and mating surfaces. Also, use (PWC03-001) engine oil to lubricate coupling nuts installed on external tubes.
Items identified on the illustrations indicate the sequence step in the text.

Special assembly instructions and torques applicable to installation are identified in the text by fits and clearances reference numbers (ie: F&C REF. NO. XXXX). Refer to the related inspection section for the table of fits and clearances.
Refer to the SPM (Chapter 70-52) for approved torque procedures.

Inspection of the run-down torque of the self-locking nuts can be necessary before the installation of the components. The run-down torque is the torque necessary to turn a non-seated bolt in a self-locking nut. Refer to the SPM (Inspection, Chapter 70-30) if no limits are given.
Make sure that all the balancing parts that are put in the engine are the same as those used in the balancing procedure.
Be careful that no material falls into the engine during assembly. If material falls into the engine, stop the assembly procedures until the material is removed from the engine.

If a clearance or an axial dimension is given in a formula to calculate the spacer thickness, the given number is the average of the clearance or the necessary axial dimension. Refer to the applicable F&C No. for the tolerance.

If the spacers are classified by their thicknesses, a table is given to identify their classes to the correct thickness (Ref. IPC). If you must grind a spacer, do not grind the spacer to a smaller dimension than the smallest dimension given in the table. If the necessary thickness makes it necessary to grind the spacer to a smaller thickness, do the procedure to calculate the thickness again.
Always use wire gages or taper feeler gages when you measure blade tip clearances.
Unless differently specified, all the threads used in the engine are right-hand threads. You must turn clockwise to tighten the parts and counterclockwise to loosen the parts.

You can heat engine cases in an oven as an alternative to using a heat gun. Do not leave the part in the oven for more time or at a higher temperature than is specified in the procedure. A part which is over-heated will damage the varnish coating. Varnish coatings that are unsatisfactory show a change in color. Repair any unsatisfactory varnish coatings.

taskproc.title: General Instructions for the Installation of the Bearings

l1item.para: Handle the bearings per the SPM (Chapter 70-35) and the Pratt and Whitney Anti-friction Bearing Manual, P/N 3040337.

Each bearing assembly is identified by a part number and by a serial number. The serial number is identified by a prefix (eg: SERIAL NUMBER, SER or S/N). This serial number is written on the inner and outer races and on the ball cages where applicable. You must keep these bearings as assemblies as identified by the serial numbers.
The bearing inner and outer races are not always installed at the same time. Keep the inner and outer races as sets (ie: serial numbers or mating numbers of races must be the same).

You must manually install the bearings on the gearshafts in one movement. Use the applicable tools with a press or a plastic hammer to make sure that the bearings are fully installed. If the bearing moves at an angle on the gearshaft during installation, remove the bearing with the applicable tools and do the installation procedure again.
The assembly of the engine, when it is fully disassembled, has two steps.

unlitem.para: The first step is to assemble the submodules (sections) of the engine. These procedures are included in the 72-XX-00, Assembly sections of this Overhaul Manual.

The second step is to install the submodules (sections) on the engine. These procedures are included in 72-00-01 and 72-00-02, Installation-01 through -04 and are presented in a format of a left and right assembler, this method to maximize the assembly time of the engine.

l1item.para: Refer to 72-00-00 Assembly-00 for the recommended sequence for the installation of all the submodules (sections) on the engine after a full overhaul or a specified repair.
The breakdown of the Engine Manual for the disassembly of the sections and of the subassemblies shows the modular philosophy of the manual.

l2item.para: The engine is disassembled into small sub-modules in section 72-00-00, Removal.
The sub-modules are then disassembled into smaller assemblies or detail parts in other sections or page blocks.

l1item.para: The charts on the Figure (Sheets 1 thru 13) show the tasks to do to fully disassemble the complete engine sections and their subassemblies.

Sheet 1 of Figure shows the disassembly sequence of the complete engine. Each block refers to an disassembly name of a section or module. Each block has a reference to a letter and sheet number for more information regarding the disassembly of that section or module.
Sheets 2 thru 13 show details of a section or module with references to pre-requisites and post-requisites.

graphic.title: Engine Disassembly

title.xref: Engine Disassembly

l1item.para: When the engine is fully disassembled, refer to the Cleaning/Inspection/Repair Manual P/N 3056631 (CIR) for the applicable Cleaning Index and the Standard Practices Manual (SPM). These documents tell you how to correctly clean the engine parts to permit a correct inspection of the parts.
The Cleaning Index is found in Cleaning-01 of each section of the CIR Manual (72-31-00 thru 72-71-00).
The CIR cleaning index contains the name and part number and the applicable SPOP to correctly clean each detail part. Each important part also has its own cleaning procedure in the related section.
If you cannot find a part name in the CIR Cleaning Index list, look at the Miscellaneous Parts Section (at the end of the Cleaning Index) to find the part and SPOP numbers.
Bolts, washers, brackets etc., are not found in the Cleaning Index. They are cleaned with SPOP 209 or SPOP 203 spray procedure.
Table 601, at the start of Cleaning-01 of each section gives task numbers applicable to each SPOP.
Refer to the Standard Practices Manual (SPM) for:

l2item.para: General cleaning procedures
Special cleaning procedures (titanium, plated or coated parts)
Cleaning data for carbon seals.

l1item.para: Refer to the Standard Practices Manual (SPM) and the Pratt and Whitney Anti-friction Bearing Cleaning Manual P/N 3040337 for the cleaning data for bearings.
To prevent damage to engine parts, all blind holes must be fully clean and dry. When you install the studs, bolts, inserts, headless pins etc., there must be no hydraulic lock.

Refer to the applicable PW600 Engine Maintenance Manual for the external engine wash Compressor and turbine desalination wash, and the Performance recovery wash procedures. (Ref. Tasks 71-00-00-160-801 thru 807).

warning.para: READ THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS BEFORE YOU USE THESE MATERIALS. SOME MATERIALS CAN BE DANGEROUS.

l1item.para: Do all inspections carefully to make sure that you find all the damages and defects on the components. The inspection procedures give the necessary instructions to make sure that the components are in a serviceable condition before they are assembled in the engine.

All inspectors must read and understand the general inspection procedures, precautions and data given in the Standard Practices Manual (Chapters 70-00, 70-30, 70-31, 70-32, 70-33 and 70-35). The SPM gives all the steps to follow for the procedures identified with a SPOP or PWA number.
Refer to Pratt & Whitney Canada Customer Support Department for possible repair procedures or inspection limits if you have a component with damage for which no limits are given.

Inspection of the run-down torque of all self-locking nuts and self-locking helical coil inserts is necessary each time you have access to them. This check is done to make sure the self-locking nuts or helical coil insert has sufficient friction on the bolt threads. Use a bolt which has the same part number as the mating bolt to measure the run-down torque. If no limits are given, refer to the SPM (Inspection, Chapter 70-30) to find the applicable limits.

The term surface damage includes all damage (such as nicks, dents, scratches, scores, corrosion pitting and oxidation) that changes only the outer surface of a component. Surface damage does not include damage which changes the internal material of a component (such as cracks, distortion and change in hardness). The term local identifies surface damage which is isolated from other surface damage.
Dents made during a hardness check are not surface damage. Do not reject a component because of such a dent and do not remove it.

You can measure the dimensions of surface damage (nicks, dents, scratches, corrosion pits, etc.) with the aid of magnification equipment, imprint process and sample comparison (sample with identified damage dimensions).

The specified repair limits for surface damage are the maximum quantity of material that you can remove to repair the part. Make sure that it is possible to remove the full damage in the specified repair limits per the applicable repair.

If the damage is more than the specified serviceable limits or the repair limits, reject the component. If you find damage that changes the function and the structural condition of the component, reject the component.
Calculate the service life of each life-limited component at each removal. Reject components that do not have sufficient remaining service life.
Make a record of all the measured dimensions and of the dimensions that are not in the specified limits.
If not differently specified, all the fits and clearances are diametrical.

If applicable, the Maximum Material Condition (MMC) symbols are shown in the datum blocks in the dimensional inspection figures. If there are no MMC symbols, the tolerance is Regardless of Feature Size (RFS).
Be careful when there is a titanium part. Refer to SPM, Chapter 72-00, 72-20, 72-45 for more data on how to move, clean, grind and repair titanium parts.
Use clean, (PWC05-053)polyethylene sheets or ( PWC05-054)bags as covers for all parts.
Non-Destructive Test

caution.para: HANDLE COMPONENTS WITH EXTREME CARE. ALWAYS WEAR CLEAN SYNTHETIC RUBBER OR LINT FREE COTTON GLOVES DURING HANDLING. PROTECT GEARS AND GEARSHAFTS BY IMMERSING OR SPRAYING WITH PRESERVATIVE OIL (PWC05-094) AND PLACE IN CLEAN PLASTIC BAG. USE CLEAN SUITABLE PROTECTIVE CONTAINERS DURING TRANSPORTATION AND STORAGE OF GEARS AND GEARSHAFTS.

l2item.para: Magnetic particle inspect gears and gearshafts per the appropriate SPOP, in accordance with the applicable Chapter/Section/Subject in this manual.

l1item.para: Visual Checks

l2item.para: Check gear teeth for:

l3item.para: Evidence of spalling. Reject if evident.
Surface pitting. Damage up to 0.005 inch deep, 0.010 inch in diameter is acceptable; provided not more than 5 pits are enclosed within a 0.250 inch diameter circle.
Raised material and sharp edges; stone to remove.

Localized nicks, dents or scratches. Remove damage up to 0.003 inch deep and 0.010 inch wide by polishing to remove sharp edges, provided a minimum of 80% of the total tooth surface contact pattern remains. Restore original surface finish. Maintain original tooth profile.

Minor wear, uneven tooth surface contact pattern; damage up to 0.003 inch deep is acceptable, provided a minimum of 80% of the total tooth surface contact pattern remains. Polish to restore original surface finish. Maintain original tooth profile.

l2item.para: Check carbon seal face for:

l3item.para: Localized nicks, dents or scratches. Damage up to 0.002 inch deep without highspots and not extending across more than 50% of sealing band width is acceptable. Lap face (Refer to the applicable Chapter/Section/Unit REPAIR procedure) if damage exceeds limits.
Runout must be within 0.001 inch.
Flatness must be within two helium light bands. Lap face (Refer to the applicable Chapter/Section/Unit REPAIR procedure) if flatness exceeds limits.
Surface finish must be within 4.0 microinch or finer.

l2item.para: Check splines for:

l3item.para: Surface pitting. Damage up to 0.005 inch deep, 0.015 inch in diameter is acceptable; provided not more than 5 pits are enclosed within 0.250 inch diameter circle.
Raised material and sharp edges. Stone to remove.

Localized nicks, dents or scratches. Remove damage up to 0.005 inch deep, 0.010 inch wide by blending to remove sharp edges, provided a minimum of 80% of the total spline surface contact pattern remains. Polish to restore original surface finish. Maintain original spline profile.
Galling. Remove damage up to 0.005 inch deep by polishing to restore original surface finish. Maintain original spline profile.

Minor wear, uneven spline surface contact pattern. Damage up to 0.005 inch deep is acceptable, provided a minimum of 80% of the total spline surface contact pattern remains: Polish to restore original surface finish. Maintain original spline profile.

l2item.para: Check threads for:

l3item.para: Surface Pitting. Damage up to 0.003 inch deep, 0.010 inch in diameter is acceptable; provided not more than 3 pits are enclosed within 0.250 inch in length.
Raised material and sharp edges. Stone to remove.

Localized nicks, dents or scratches. Remove damage up to 0.005 inch deep, 0.010 inch wide by blending to remove sharp edges, provided a minimum of 90% of the total threads surface contact pattern remains. Polish to restore original surface finish. Maintain original thread profile.
Galling. Remove damage up to 0.005 inch deep by polishing to restore original surface finish. Maintain original thread profile.
Minor wear. Damage up to 0.003 inch deep is acceptable.
Proper mating nut engagement.

l2item.para: Check packing seals and retaining rings grooves and slots for:

l3item.para: Surface pitting. Damage up to 0.005 inch deep, 0.015 inch in diameter is acceptable; provided not more than 5 pits are enclosed within 0.250 inch diameter circle.
Raised material and sharp edges. Stone to remove.
Localized nicks, dents or scratches. Remove damage up to 0.005 inch deep, 0.010 inch wide by blending to remove sharp edges. Polish to restore original surface finish.
Minor Wear. Damage up to 0.005 inch deep is acceptable.

l2item.para: Check oil holes for cleanliness and obstruction of any foreign material.

caution.para: DIAMETERS IN DIRECT CONTACT WITH BEARINGS HAVING NO INNER RACE MUST NOT BE PLATED.

l2item.para: Check diameters for: (in direct contact with bearings having no inner races).

note.para: Diameters in contact with bearings having inner races or snap diameters, shall be nickel plated.
Diameters in contact with oil seals or sleeve bearings shall be chrome plated.

l3item.para: Evidence of spalling. Reject if evident.
Surface pitting. Damage up to 0.005 inch deep, 0.010 inch in diameter is acceptable; provided not more than 5 pits are enclosed within 0.250 inch diameter circle.
Raised material and sharp edges. Stone to remove.

Localized nicks, dents, or scratches. Remove damage up to 0.003 in. deep, 0.010 inch wide and spaced at least 0.100 inch apart by polishing to remove sharp edges. Restore original surface roundness and surface finish. Avoid producing flat spots.

note.para: No other repairs are allowed to bearing journal.

l2item.para: Check diameters and adjacent faces for: (in contact with bearings having inner races, oil seals, sleeve bearings or snap diameters).

l3item.para: Surface pitting. Damage up to 0.005 inch deep, 0.015 inch in diameter is acceptable; provided not more than 5 pits are enclosed within 0.250 inch diameter circle.
Raised material and sharp edges. Stone to remove.

Localized nicks, dents. Remove damage up to 0.005 inch deep, 0.010 inch wide and spaced at least 0.050 inch apart by blending to remove sharp edges. Polish to restore original surface roundness of diameters and flatness of faces, and original surface finish

Localized scratches or scores. Remove damage up to 0.005 inch deep, 0.010 inch wide and spaced at least 0.050 inch apart by blending to remove sharp edges. Polish to restore original surface roundness of diameters and flatness of faces and original surface finish.
Repair Diameters. If damage exceeds limits, refer to the applicable Chapter/Section/Unit REPAIR procedure.

l2item.para: Check all other surfaces for:

l3item.para: Surface pitting. Damage up to 0.005 inch deep, 0.015 inch in diameter is acceptable; provided not more than 5 pits are enclosed within 0.250 inch diameter circle.
Raised material and sharp edges. Stone to remove.

Localized nicks, dents or scratches. Remove damage up to 0.010 inch deep, 0.010 inch wide by blending to remove sharp edges. Polish to restore original surface finish. Maintain original profiles, contours and radii.

l2item.para: Check all surfaces for:

l3item.para: Minor surface stain. Corrosion deposits up to 0.001 inch deep in all surfaces except diameters in direct contact with bearings having no inner races, carbon seal face, oil seal diameters and oil holes by wet glass bead blasting per SPOP 16. Mask 'excepted' surfaces before blasting.

Remove minor surface stain, corrosion deposits up to 0.001 inch deep in diameters in direct contact with bearings having no inner races, and oil seals diameters by polishing. Restore original surface finish.
Reinspect surfaces for pitting per preceding paragraphs.

l1item.para: Circumferential scratches in tubes are acceptable provided they do not exceed a 45 degree arc on circumference. Accept any number of scratches; they may be blended out, provided depth of blend does not exceed one quarter of the wall thickness of tube.
Any number of longitudinal scratches is acceptable, provided they do not exceed one-half inch in length.
Nicks and chafing in tubes is acceptable, provided three-quarters of the wall thickness remains after blending. Each blended area must not exceed one-half square inch.
Minor dents in tubes are acceptable, provided there are no restrictions to flow, caused by sharp edges or corners. Dents are unacceptable within one inch of ferrule scarf-welds, or in a blended area.
Minor, isolated pitting is acceptable, if not greater than 0.003 inch in depth. Clusters of pits should be blended out to a maximum depth of 0.005 inch.
Rust and stains on tubes are acceptable, if they can be removed by light polishing with a very mild abrasive.
During the inspection, keep a record of the items that follow:

unlitem.para: The condition of all the examined components
The thickness of the adjustment spacers

l1item.para: When you write the inspection records or reports, use only words which accurately identify the damage and the condition of the components. Use names given in the Standard Practices Manual (Visual Inspection, Chapter 70-31). This will prevent the use of different words to identify the same condition.
You can attach tags to the components to show their conditions (serviceable, repairable or unserviceable). The tags must contain all applicable data as follows:

unlitem.para: Engine total time and total cycles
Component total time and total cycles

l1item.para: Do not let components that can corrode stay without protection. There must always be a layer of lubricating oil on the bearings.

If not differently specified, when a part is frozen before the installation, make sure that clean engine oil (PWC03-001) is applied on it and that it is put in a polyethylene bag (PWC05-054) before it goes in the freezer.
The preservation procedures that follow are for a normal period of time necessary to do an engine overhaul or repair.
For short-time preservations (7 days maximum) do as follows:

l2item.para: Apply protection on all the surfaces of components that can corrode (this does not include bearings) after the repair. Use (PWC15-007) corrosion inhibitor solution (water soluble) and put the components in (PWC05-054)polyethylene bags.

For engine bearings (or components that have bearings installed on them), apply (PWC03-001)clean engine oil on all surfaces of the bearings after the repair. Then put them in (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

l1item.para: For longer preservation times do as follows:

l2item.para: Apply protection on all the surfaces of components that can corrode (this does not include bearings). Use (PWC15-003)corrosion preventive oil and put the components in ( PWC05-054)polyethylene bags.

For engine bearings (or components that have bearings installed on them), apply clean, (PWC05-094)synthetic preservation oil on all surfaces of the engine bearings after the repair. Then put them in (PWC05-054)polyethylene bags.

note.para: It is the responsibility of each shop to do the preservation procedure again as necessary per their own experience and the shop environmental conditions.

caution.para: BE CAREFUL, THE CARBON SEAL IS A VERY FRAGILE PART.

l1item.para: Handle the carbon seals per the SPM (Chapter 70-00).
Do not manually push on the contact face of the carbon seal. This will cause local stresses in the carbon seal and will cause a malfunction of the spring mechanism.
The engine heavy maintenance or repair inspection sequence is as follows:

note.para: Heavy maintenance includes hot section inspection and life item replacement.

unlitem.para: Visual inspection of the disassembled and removed component
Visual inspection of the components installed in the engine to which you have access
Visual inspection of the remaining assembled engine modules or submodules

l1item.para: The overhaul Inspection/Check types (72-XX-00) in the CIR manual are as follows:

l2item.para: Inspection/Check-00 is the index of the different Inspection/Checks. The data that follows is given where applicable:

unlitem.para: The Inspection/Check types and their applicability for the components
The component part numbers and the applicable Inspection/Check types

l2item.para: Inspection/Check-01 is the nondestructive inspection. The data that follows is given where applicable:
Inspection/Check-02 is the visual inspection. The data that follows is given where applicable:
Inspection/Check-03 is the dimensional inspection. The data that follows is given where applicable:
Inspection/Check-04 is the functional check. The data that follows is given where applicable:

task.title: Engine Heavy Maintenance or Repair Inspection - General

warning.para: READ THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS BEFORE YOU USE THESE MATERIALS. SOME MATERIALS CAN BE DANGEROUS.

note.para: Heavy maintenance includes hot section inspection and life item replacement.

l1item.para: When a module or a submodule is disassembled for engine heavy maintenance or repair, it is necessary to do a visual inspection of all the removed components and all other installed submodule components to which you have access.
If it is necessary to grind the shroud segments, keep the blade tip clearance to a minimum to get better engine performance.
If it is necessary to replace the HP turbine assembly, make sure that the trim balance weights (Ref. engine data plate) are installed on the new turbine assembly.
After an engine repair or heavy maintenance that can affect engine performance, do an engine test. Refer to Testing-00 (Task 72-00-00-700-801) .
The engine heavy maintenance or repair inspection sequence is as follows:

unlitem.para: Visual inspection of the disassembled and removed component
Visual inspection of the components installed in the engine to which you have access
Visual inspection of the remaining assembled engine modules or submodules.

l1item.para: If more disassembly is necessary, refer to the disassembly charts in Disassembly-00 (Task 72-00-00-000-802) to find the section and disassembly numbers of the necessary procedures. Then, do the related inspections of the disassembled subassembly or submodule components (Ref. CIR manual).
Inspection/Check-00, in the Overhaul Manual sections 72-00-00, gives all the necessary procedures to do the assembly of the engine components.
Make a record of all the measured dimensions and of the dimensions that are not in the specified limits.
If not differently specified, all the fits and clearances are diametral.
The Inspection Frequency Requirement (IFR) codes in the Overhaul Manual are not used. The fit, clearance, torque or special procedure is to be done at each assembly of the affected parts.
No letter (after a limit) is an indication of a loose fit (clearance).
The letter T (after a limit) is an indication of a tight fit.
A maximum limit of zero with the letter T (eg 0.000T) is an indication that there must not be any looseness between the components when they are assembled.

The term BY SELECTION is an indication that you get the correct fit or clearance by selection of the components. You can use the measured dimensions of the mating components or you can assemble the mating components to make the selection.
The term FIT TO is an indication that you get the correct fit or clearance at the assembly operation by grinding, reaming or other specified procedures.

When you measure a FIR tolerance of a surface with a dial indicator, ignore local indications that are not in the specified limit if they are caused by surface damage or other minor damage. The surface damage must be in the serviceable or repair limits of the applicable visual inspection (Ref. CIR).

taskproc.title: Engine General - Fits and Clearances
taskproc.para: The following Table gives the torques and special assembly limits.

table.title: Engine General - Fits and Clearances (Ref. Fig. 801)

caution.para: THE FITS AND CLEARANCES ARE DIAMETRAL IF NOT DIFFERENTLY SPECIFIED.

numlitem.para: No engine oil allowed on nut or shaft threads.

Prior to installation, apply (PWC06-009)antiseize compound to the nut and shaft threads and nut thrust face and its mating face. Re-application of the antiseize compound is required following each subsequent installation. Remove excess compound wherever possible.
Do not exceed 3750 lb.in. torque. If this value is reached before minimum angle of turns. Check parts for binding or damage. Re-apply (PWC06-009) antiseize compound and correct as required.
Install nut and tighten 300 to 400 lbf.in. (33.90-45.20 Nm).
Establish common reference points between nut and mating parts.
Turn nut through angle of 82 to 84 degrees.
Loosen nut to 0 lbf.in. (zero Nm).
Torque the nut 300 to 400 lbf.in. (33.90-45.20 Nm).

If nut reference point is within 3 degrees either side of the mating part reference point, apply final angle of turn of 82 to 84 degrees. A further angle of turn of 4.5 degrees may be applied for the keywasher alignment. However, do not exceed an angle of turn more then 90 degrees.
If nut reference point are not within limits, repeat steps (3) through (8), until reference points are within limits, then perform step (9).
No engine oil allowed on nut or shaft threads.
Prior to installation, apply (PWC06-004)antiseize compound to the bolt and shaft threads and bolt thrust face and its mating face. Remove excess compound wherever possible.
Install bolt and cupwasher, thread finger tight.
Torque bolt 25 to 35 lbf.in. (2.82-3.95 Nm).
Apply a reference mark on cupwasher and bearing to check for shearing of cupwasher tabs.
Turn bolt through angle of 13 to 16 degrees.
If torque exceeds 400 lbf.in. (45.19 Nm), remove bolt, check parts for binding or damage and repeat steps (2), (3) and (4).
If torque is below 400 lbf.in. (45.19 Nm), loosen bolt to 0 lbf.in. (0 Nm).
Torque bolt 25 to 35 lbf.in. (2.82-3.95 Nm).
Turn bolt through final angle of 17 to 20 degrees.
If final torque is below 160 lbf.in. (18.08 Nm), loosen bolt to 0 lbf.in. (0 Nm) and repeat steps (4), (6) thru (9), until torque is within final limits.

If maximum torque exceeds 500 lbf.in. (56.49 Nm) before the final angle of turn is applied remove bolt, check parts for binding or damage and repeat steps (2), (3), (4), (6) thru (9) until torque is within final limits.
Check that reference marks are aligned.
No engine oil allowed on nut or shaft threads.
Apply (PWC06-009) antiseize compound to the nut and tie-shaft rear threads, cupwasher and nut mating face.
Install cupwasher and nut, thread hand tight.
Apply stretch load of 14500 to 16000 lbf to tie-shaft. The stretch load must not exceed 20000 lbf.
Thread the nut hand tight
Release load on tie-shaft. Residual stretch measured between the HP disk and the tie-shaft end face must be 0.012 to 0.013 in. (0.305-0.330 mm).
: Finish the installation of the cupwasher to provide the cupwasher anti-rotation with the HPT nut.
: Refer to F & C REF. NO. 1818.

unlitem.para: Torque the cable nut, 115 to 135 lbf.in. (13.0-15.3 Nm).
Torque the igniter, 300 to 360 lbf.in. (33.9-40.7 Nm).
Torque the cable nut, 115 to 135 lbf.in. (13.0-15.3 Nm).

entry.para: Crimp cup washer at 4 locations and keep clearances as follows:

numlitem.para: 0.022 in. (0.56 mm) maximum at location EB (8 totals).
0.025 in. (0.64 mm) maximum at location EC (4 totals).
0.030 in. (0.76 mm) permitted at 1 of the 4 EC locations (1 total).

entry.para: Crimp cup washer at 4 locations and keep clearances as follows:

numlitem.para: 0.000 in. (0.00 mm) maximum at location EB (8 totals).
0.015 in. (0.38 mm) maximum at location EC (4 totals).

title.xref: Engine General - Fits and Clearances (Ref. Table 801)
Engine General - Fits and Clearances (Ref. Fig. 801)

task.title: Engine Visual Check before Heavy Maintenance, Repair or Overhaul

numlitem.para: Do this procedure when you get the engine (before disassembly). The checks necessary when the engine is not fully disassembled (during heavy maintenance or repair inspection) are given in Para. 3.

l1item.para: Before you do heavy maintenance, a repair or an overhaul on the engine, P&WC recommends that you do a visual check to find the initial condition of the engine assembly. This check is also necessary to find how many components were not sent with the engine and to find components that are not part of the basic engine.
Refer to the Illustrated Parts Catalog (IPC) for the external configuration of the engine and the part numbers and part names of the components of the basic engine.

Look for damaged or missing accessories and for accessories that are not part of the basic engine. Make a record of what you find and of all the part numbers and serial numbers of the accessories. Photographs of the engine is recommended for record purposes.

Look for damaged or missing external tubes, cables, valve assemblies, filter housings, covers, insulation blankets, brackets, clamps and other external components. Also, look for components that are not part of the basic engine. Make a record of what you find.
Make a record of the damaged or missing external components and of the components that are not part of the basic engine.
Examine the housings for important damage, for leaks and for distortion. Make a record of the damaged components and of the locations of leaks.
Examine the LP compressor through the inlet area and examine the LP turbine blades through the exhaust area for important damage. Make a record of the damage.

numlitem.para: Do this procedure during engine heavy maintenance or repair (when the engine is not fully disassembled).
Do this procedure before and after engine shipping.

l1item.para: During engine heavy maintenance or repair, it is necessary to do a visual check of the engine to make sure that the remaining modules or submodules, which are not disassembled, are in a serviceable condition.

Before and after engine shipping (before engine installation in the airframe), P&WC recommends that you do a visual check of the engine assembly. This check helps to find and correct damage that can occur when the engine is moved or when work is done on it.

If a repair, removal, disassembly, inspection or installation is necessary, refer to the How to Use section of the related module or component to find the applicable sections where you will find these procedures.
Refer to the Illustrated Parts Catalog (IPC) for data about the external configuration of the engine and the part numbers and part names of the basic components of the engine.
Examine the accessories for important damage, looseness, leaks and broken or missing safetywire/safety cable.

l2item.para: Replace or repair damaged accessories.
Remove accessories which show looseness or leaks with their related seals, gaskets and packings. Install the accessories with new seals, gaskets and packings.
Replace broken or missing safetywire/safety cable.

l1item.para: Examine the wiring harness assembly and probes for important damage, looseness and for broken or missing safetywire/safety cable.

l2item.para: Replace or repair damaged components.
Remove loose probes. Examine them for damage and install them with new packings, gaskets and seals.
Disconnect the loose wiring harness connections. Examine them for damage then correctly connect them.

l1item.para: Examine the ignition cables and the igniters for important damage, looseness and for broken or missing safetywire.

l2item.para: Repair or replace damaged cables or igniters.
Remove the loose cables or igniters. Examine them for damage then install them.
Replace broken or missing safetywire/safety cable.

l1item.para: Examine all the external tubes for important damage, dents, bends, looseness and leaks.

l2item.para: Repair or replace tubes with important damage.
Replace tubes with dents deeper than 10 percent of the outer diameter or with sharp bends in radii.
Remove loose tubes. Examine them for damage then install the tubes with new packings and seals.
Remove tubes which have leaks. Find and correct the cause of the leaks.

l1item.para: Examine all housings, cases, covers and ducts for important damage, distortion, loss of paint and leaks.

l2item.para: Do a local paint touch-up on painted housings with bare metal areas.
Unpainted housings, with local dents in non-functional surfaces but without cracks or sharp corners, are permitted if there is no distortion.
Disassemble damaged housings to permit repair or replacement.
Find and correct the cause of the leaks.

l1item.para: Make sure that all brackets and plugs are tight and correctly locked.
Make sure that all the covers and shipping closures are installed.

caution.para: BE CAREFUL WITH THE BORESCOPE. THE BORESCOPE CAN BE EASILY DAMAGED BY SHOCK, TWISTING AND PINCHING. DO NOT EXPOSE THE BORESCOPE TO RADIATION.
DO NOT PUT THE BORESCOPE IN LIQUIDS.

l1item.para: Use the borescope inspection to find the causes of performance deterioration and to make an analysis of the internal condition of the engine. You can get access through ports or openings made by the removal of covers or components.
Refer to the applicable PW600 maintenance manual for all borescope information.

caution.para: DO NOT DO A BORESCOPE INSPECTION IF THE ENGINE INTERNAL TEMPERATURE IS MORE THAN 66°C (150°F). HIGH TEMPERATURES CAN DAMAGE THE BORESCOPE.

l1item.para: The usual cooling time after engine shutdown is 40 minutes. If necessary, do dry motoring runs to make the engine cool faster.

During a borescope inspection, carefully examine the damaged area to make sure that it is not a repaired area. The limits for an area which was repaired before can be more than the limits which are permitted for a defect.

task.title: Transfer of Chip Detector Particles/Identification of Particles

l1item.para: Refer to the applicable PW600 Maintenance Manual for details.

note.para: Refer to the applicable PW600 Maintenance Manual (Task 72-00-00-290-801 thru 803) for the complete instructions to perform an HSI. The engine is disassembled from the turbine exhaust duct to the combustion-chamber liner.

tprereq.title: Pre-requisites
tprereq.para: Do an engine test per Testing-00 (Task 72-00-00-700-801) . Make a record of the engine performance.

l1item.para: The Hot Section Inspection (HSI) is the inspection of the components that are in the gas path. This inspection is necessary because of the deterioration of the hot section components which occurs during the usual operation of the engine. This deterioration changes the engine performance and the hot section inspection is done to get the maximum life from the components and to make sure that the engine performance is satisfactory between overhauls.
If it is necessary to grind the shroud segments, keep the blade tip clearance to a minimum to get better engine performance.
The engine test, done before and after a hot section inspection, will show the effect of the hot section inspection on the engine performance.

subtask.title: Life-limited Parts Analysis

l1item.para: Make an analysis of the life-limited components of the engine. refer to the applicable PW600 Engine Maintenance Manual, for the life limit.
Replace components which have no remaining service life. Refer to Inspection/Check-06 (Task 72-00-00-280-830) to find the references for the necessary procedures.
Do an engine test per Testing-00 (Task 72-00-00-700-801).
The unscheduled maintenance checks or inspections are necessary when special or unusual conditions occur or when the performance of the engine is not satisfactory.
For unusual conditions or special faults, for which no instructions are given in this inspection, refer to the procedures given in the applicable Maintenance Manual Fault Isolation section.
An engine with special or unusual conditions can go back into service after the applicable unscheduled maintenance checks or inspections are completed.

The engine operator must supply data about the special or unusual conditions (eg: engine rotor speed, engine temperature, amount of time during which the condition occurred) for which the engine is repaired. This data is mandatory to find the necessary level of repair.
If the engine operator did not supply the mandatory data for the specified special or unusual condition, repair the engine for the worst possible condition.
Refer to the Standard Overhaul Procedures (Chapter 70-00), in the Standard Practices Manual for general instructions, precautions and data for damaged engines and engine parts.

If a rotor assembly has an important failure (eg: turbine blade fracture, bearing failure, impeller blade fracture, turbine shaft fracture), make sure that the related main bearings are discarded. The main bearings can have damage related to the failure that is not easy to find.
If a module, submodule, subassembly or component is disassembled, it is necessary to examine it for damage per the related inspections.
If a cleaning or an inspection for a detail component is mandatory per the unscheduled maintenance check or inspection, refer to the related section number given in the procedure.
After each unscheduled check or inspection, do an engine test per Testing-00 (Task 72-00-00-700-801), to make sure that the engine performance is satisfactory.

note.para: The bearing inspection procedures only apply to the repair and unscheduled engine removal only. When the engine is returned for a scheduled overhaul, all the bearings must be discarded.

l1item.para: Handle the bearings per the SPM (Chapter 70-35) and per the Care, Cleaning and Handling of Anti-friction Bearings Manual P&WC P/N 3040337.

Each bearing assembly is identified by a part number and a serial number. The serial number is identified by a prefix (eg. SERIAL NUMBER, SER or S/N). This serial number is written on the inner and outer races and on the ball cages where applicable. You must keep these bearings as assemblies as identified by the serial number.
Make a record of the serial numbers and the locations of the bearings removed to make sure that the serviceable bearings are installed in their initial locations.
The bearing inner and outer races are not always removed at the same time. Keep the inner and outer races as sets, (i.e: serial numbers or mating numbers of races must be the same).

Standard anti-friction bearing visual inspection procedures are described in PWA Overhaul Standard Practices Manual (Ref. Chapter 70-35, ANTI-FRICTION BEARING INSPECTION) and in the Anti-friction Bearings Overhaul Visual Inspection Standard Manual (P/N 3039731), NDT instructions can be omitted. The procedures include: general precautions, inspection reports, unpacking new bearings, inspection areas, feel tests, scriber tracing, visual inspection and bearing protection.
No bearing repairs are permitted other than the repairs contained in the P&WC approved manuals or in the Anti-friction Bearings Overhaul Visual Inspection Standard Manual (P/N 3039731).

tprereq.title: Pre-requisites
tprereq.para: Refer to Unscheduled Maintenance Inspection - General (Task 72-00-00-280-812) for general data.

l1item.para: Engine overtemperature conditions are specified into three sets of categories (Ref. Maintenance Manual).

unlitem.para: Category B (rectify at the maintenance level)

l1item.para: When overtemperature in Category B has been rectified at a maintenance facility, no further action is required.
When overtemperature conditions are in Category C, do as follows:

unlitem.para: Rotating components, do non-destructive-testing followed by a visual inspection and a growth check (if applicable).
Non-rotating components, do a visual inspection only and repair as required.

l1item.para: Do an overtemperature inspection of the Compressor Case and the Turbine Support Case (TSC) as follows:

l2item.para: Disassemble the engine sufficiently to gain access to the inside of the compressor case and the TSC (i.e. exhaust case, LP and HP disk, combustor).

l3item.para: Inspect the inside of the compressor case and the diffuser case for visual evidence of overtemperature. If no evidence is observed, the compressor case is acceptable as is. If evidence of overtemperture is present, remove and inspect the compressor case per the CIR Manual P/N 3056631.

l2item.para: Disassemble the HP and LP disk (Ref. CIR Manual P/N 3056631) and proceed as follows.

l3item.para: Do a fluorescent penetrant inspection of the HP and the LP blades and disks per SPOP 84.
Do a microstructural analysis of two HP blades (Ref. PWA Standard Practices Manual P/N 585005, Section 70-36-20).

The two HP blades should be sent first for the metallurgical analysis to determine the extent of damage. If the HP blade analysis shows unacceptable conditions, then two of the LP blades will need to be sent for metallurgical analysis. (Ref. PWA Standard Practices Manual P/N 585005, Section 70-36-20).
Do a growth dimension check on the HP and LP disks per the CIR Manual P/N 3056631.
Do a hardness check on the HP and LP disks per the CIR Manual P/N 3056631.

l2item.para: Inspect the fuel manifold for evidence of overtemperature and do a flow check per the CMM instructions. If evidence of overtemperature is observed, discard the manifold, packings and support pins.
Inspect the T6 system components for evidence of overtemperature. (Ref. CIR Manual P/N 3056631).
Visually inspect the remaining exposed components for evidence of overtemperature.

l1item.para: Repair or replace the defective module, submodules, subassemblies or components.

This information should be used as a guide for metallic contamination identification and not as a specification of engine serviceability. Qualified personnel should carefully analyze the unusual oil conditions prevailing on the engine and determine the extent of disassembly necessary to correct the problem .
When metal contaminants are evident, consideration must be given to particle/flake size, shape and engine operating history.
A particle is a piece of metal of finite thickness, large enough in area to become entrapped on the main oil filter surface.
A flake is a metal chip having immeasurable thickness, but large enough to become entrapped on the main oil filter surface.
Examples of possible metallic contamination:

l2item.para: Small flakes of non-ferrous metal normally originate from plain bearings or bushings of babbitt, tin bronze or silver.
Small flakes of ferrous metal normally originate from spalled anti-friction bearings, gear teeth or from fretting.
Silvers of steel normally originate from interference between steel parts or from heavy scoring.

l1item.para: After a fire extinguisher has been used on the engine, consideration must be given to the possibility that the extinguishing agent has contaminated the oil system.
Unusual oil conditions (Part A)

l2item.para: Oil pressure fluctuation below or above the continuous time limit (Ref. Fig. related to a loss of engine oil.
Oil pressure drop below or oil pressure increase above the continuous time limit (Ref. Fig. .
No metal particles found or less than 40 non-magnetic particles found in main oil filter.
Contamination by fire extinguishing agent.

l1item.para: Unusual oil conditions (Part B)

l2item.para: Oil pressure fluctuation below or above the continuous time limit (Ref. Fig. related to a loss of engine oil.
Oil pressure drop below or oil pressure increase above the continuous time limit (Ref. Fig. .
Engine with an oil filter bypass event.
Metal particles found in main oil filter or chip detector.
The oil sample analysis refers to material AMS6444 (52100) and/or AMS6491 (M50) and/or AMS6414 and/or AMS615.
Any magnetic particles or more than 40 non-magnetic particles found in main oil filter.

l1item.para: Rectify condition (Part A)

l2item.para: When source of problem has been determined, separate the engine into subassemblies.
Disassemble, clean, visually inspect and repair suspect subassemblies and accessory components per the borescope limit, maintenance manual or CIR manual.
Assemble the specified components per the related assembly procedures.
Assemble the engine. Refer to the installation charts in Installation-00, (Task 72-00-00-400-801) to find data for the necessary procedures.
Test the engine. Refer to Testing-00, (Task 72-00-00-700-801) to find data for the necessary procedures.

l1item.para: Rectify condition (Part B in addition to Part A)

l2item.para: Disassemble the engine to get all the components that ran in oil (e.g. Bearing, Gear).
Replace the air and oil separator installed on the accessory drive gearshaft assembly (Task 72-61-02-040-801).
Replace all non-demountable & semi-demountable bearings in the affected area.
Inspect all demountable bearings in the affected area.
When a bearing is the main source of the metal contamination, the other bearing on the same rotor/gearshaft must be discarded.
Remove the externals and accessories listed below:

unlitem.para: Oil Filter Housing and Check Valve

l2item.para: Disassemble, clean, flush, visually inspect and repair suspect accessory components.
Remove the FMU from the accessory gearbox. Do a visual inspection of the FMU drive gearshaft inside the accessory gearbox. No damage is acceptable.

Do a full inspection of the accessories as per the applicable component maintenance manual (Ref. Introduction for applicable CMM P/N).
If the engine was immersed while running, or less than 40 minutes after shutdown, disassemble engine and do a full scheduled overhaul inspection (Ref. PW600 CIR Manual P/N 3056631).

l2item.para: Make sure you examine the hot section parts for signs of possible distortion.
Examine bearings and aluminum casings carefully for signs of corrosion.

Do a florescent penetrant inspection of the suspected areas per SPOP 70.
Do an inspection of the engine and accessory mounts pads, and all cast housings for cracks.
Do an inspection of all ducting and cases for buckling, distortion and cracks.
Do an inspection of all tubing, pressure sensing lines, brackets and sheet metal parts for distortion.

l1item.para: Examine inlet and exhaust duct areas for damage consistent with the passage of a foreign object.
Turn LP compressor rotor by hand and check that compressor turns freely with no indication of obstructions, roughness or abnormal noise.

l2item.para: If any FOD defect is apparent and no obstruction, roughness or abnormal noise is found, do the following.

Use a borescope through the LP compressor rotor blades to examine the HP Compressor rotor for evidence of FOD. If no damage is found to the HP compressor rotor, proceed with the repair of the LP compressor rotor.

If damage is found, examine the HP impeller for FOD. If no damage is found on the impeller, proceed with the repair of the LP and HP compressor rotor by removing the LP fan and some fan exit vanes (Ref. Maintenance Manual); enough to provide access to the HP compressor rotor.
If the HP impeller has damage, remove the impeller and access to the LP turbine rotor for a visual inspection for FOD on the blades, vane airfoils and the diffuser pipes.

l1item.para: If obstruction, roughness or abnormal noise is found, disassemble the engine and investigate until the problem is found.
If no evidence of foreign object damage is found in inlet areas continue as follows:

l2item.para: Borescope the HP compressor rotor per Para. (2).
Examine the fan case stator vanes, bypass case and exhaust duct for evidence of impact damage.
If no damage is found, assemble the engine. Refer to the installation charts in Installation-00 (Task 72-00-00-400-801) to find data for the necessary procedures.
If evidence of foreign object damage is found, disassemble the engine to remove the LP compressor set and, if necessary, the HP impeller, HP impeller housing and diffuser.

task.title: Engine on Which Fire Extinguishing Agent Was Applied

l1item.para: The use of fire extinguishing agents or compounds (of which sodium bicarbonate, potassium bicarbonate and bromotrifluoromethane are the most common) can result in corrosive attach on both hot and cold section engine components. The severity of corrosive attack is largely dependent upon the temperature to which the chemicals are exposed within the engine.
Engines contaminated by fire extinguishing agents are classified into separate categories for light overhaul as follows:

l2item.para: Where fires have been external or have been confined to the burner and turbine gas path, and overtemperature limits have not been exceeded, carry out light overhaul procedures as outlined in this paragraph.
Where overtemperature limits have been exceeded and fire extinguishing agent contamination is present, carry out light overhaul procedures as outlined in Para. 2., and this paragraph.

warning.para: READ THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS BEFORE YOU WORK ON THE ENGINE. SOME FIRE EXTINGUISHING AGENTS CAN BE DANGEROUS (REFER TO THE AMM).
YOU MUST WEAR THE PROPER PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT (I.E. SAFETY GLASSES, GLOVES BOOTS, ETC) WHEN HANDLING THE ENGINE.

l1item.para: Engines returned to an overhaul facility due to contamination by fire extinguishing agents have been washed internally and externally prior to removal from the airframe (Ref. Aircraft Maintenance Manual).
Remove any residual deposits of fire extinguishing agents and repair corrosion damage to engine with minimum possible delay (Ref. PW600 CIR Manual P/N 3056631).
Remove engine from container (Ref. Maintenance Manual).
Remove externals from engine.
If oil system contamination is suspected, treat as for unusual oil conditions (Ref. Para. 4.).

warning.para: READ THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS BEFORE YOU USE THESE MATERIALS. SOME MATERIALS CAN BE DANGEROUS.

l1item.para: The specific repairs location in the CIR Manual for all important components are given in their related sections. The general instructions and data for general repair procedures are given in this section.

All persons who repair components must read and understand the Standard Overhaul Procedures given in the Standard Practices Manual (Chapter 70-00). The (SPM) gives the necessary steps for the procedures identified with a SPOP or PWA number.

Oversize studs are to be installed as replacements for those parts which are stretched, loose or have damaged threads. Should a stud which is already oversize require replacement, use the next oversize stud. Use the correct stud drivers to insert new studs and torque to values given (Ref. 70-52, P&WC Standard Practices Manual). The Illustrated Parts Catalog for the engine will provide part numbers and location of studs.

When threads of a stud hole are damaged beyond dimensions suitable for a maximum oversized stud, it may be repaired by using a helical coil insert. The IPC will provide part numbers and locations of suitable helical coil inserts. Before other methods of replacing studs are attempted - e.g. inserts or solid inserts - ensure that sufficient material remains around the repair so as not to impair the integrity of cavity walls, etc.
Ensure damaged hole is suitable for repair.
Measure core depth of existing hole.
Select appropriate drill and drill hole to depth measured in step (2), preceding.
Using appropriate size special tap, thread hole one thread deeper than insert to be installed.
Where applicable, counterbore to required angle and depth.
Clean out hole and ensure freedom from swarf or other foreign matter.
If part is magnesium, treat tapped hole by swabbing or brushing with chrome pickle touch-up solution as specified in SPOP 41.
Using appropriate helicoil insert installing tool screw in insert (tang first) to finish 1 to 1-1/2 pitch (threads) below surface of part or below counterbore, whichever applies.
Cut off driving tang or notch, using recommended tang break-off tool.
Subject repaired hole to critical inspection.
Remove unserviceable insert, using recommended extracting tool.
Install new insert as described above.

The term surface damage includes all damage (such as nicks, dents, scratches, scores, corrosion pitting and oxidation) that changes only the outer surface of a component. Surface damage does not change the internal material of a component (such as cracks, distortion, spalling and changes in hardness). The term local is used for surface damage that is isolated from other damage.
Dents made during a hardness check are not surface damage. Do not reject a component because of such a dent and do not remove it.

Some surface damage can be serviceable without repair, but P&WC recommends the removal of all surface damage unless differently specified. The sharper the surface damage, the more P&WC recommends that you remove the damage.

The specified repair limits for surface damage are the maximum quantity of material that you can remove to repair the part. You must remove the full damage in the specified repair limits per the applicable repair.
Keep the material removal to a minimum to get the maximum life and operation from the component.
Use only hand tools.

All local surface-damage removal must extend to an area at least 15 times the depth of the damage. The surface finish of the repaired area must be as smooth or smoother than the surface finish before the damage. The repair marks must be the same as the machining tool marks before the damage.

When you remove only the raised material and sharp edges related to damage, do not remove all the damage that caused the raised material and sharp edges. If not differently specified, polish the repaired area to make the surface finish of the repaired area as smooth or smoother than the surface finish before the damage. The repair marks must be the same as the machining tool marks before the damage.

Do not let components that can corrode stay without protection for long intervals. Also, do not let bearings dry with no protection. There must always be a layer of oil on the bearings. Then put them in (PWC05-054)polyethylene bags or seal them with (PWC05-053) polyethylene sheets.

Apply protection on all the surfaces of components that can corrode (this does not include engine bearings) after each repair. Use (PWC05-035) corrosion preventive oil and put the components in (PWC05-054) polyethylene bags.

For engine bearings (or components that have bearings installed on them), apply clean synthetic (PWC05-094)preservation oil on all the surfaces of the engine bearings after each repair. Then put them in (PWC05-054)polyethylene bags or seal them with (PWC05-053) polyethylene sheets.
Apply protection again after four days of storage.

warning.para: READ THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS BEFORE YOU USE THESE MATERIALS. SOME MATERIALS CAN BE DANGEROUS.

l1item.para: Using a suitable drill, partially remove flared end of swaged nut. Do not drill through swaged nut to contact flange.
Remove swaged nut, using a parallel pin punch to shear weakened flare and remove defective swaged nut from case.
Install new shank nut by inserting through rear face of mounting flange.
Lightly lubricate tapered portion of (PWC31771-100)spreader with ( PWC03-001)engine oil, and screw into shank nut until swaging end is flared against flange.
Remove spreader and examine flared end of shank nut for correct forming. There must be no evidence of deformation or cracking.

subtask.title: Pre-packaging Checks

note.para: Put suitable containers or drip pan under engine.

l1item.para: Remove the oil tank drain plug726173PP26011 from the bottom of the accessory gearbox. Remove and discard the preformed packing726173RP03011 .
Remove the magnetic chip detector792172PP26041 and packings792172RP03012 . Discard the packings.
Remove the chip detector valve792163PV01041 and packing792163RP03011 . Discard the packing.
Allow a minimum of 15 minutes for the oil to fully drain from the engine.
Install the chip detector valve as follows:

l2item.para: Lubricate the packing792163RP03011 with ( PWC03-001)engine oil and install it on the self-closing valve792163PV01041 .
Install the self-closing valve. Torque the valve to 150 to 170 lb.in. (17.0-19.0 Nm).

l1item.para: Install the magnetic chip detector as follows:

l2item.para: Lubricate the packings792172RP03012 with ( PWC03-001)engine oil and install it on the detector792172PP26041 .
Hold the chip detector and align the locking tabs with the slot on the self-closing valve.
Put the chip detector into the self-closing valve. Push the chip detector into the valve and turn it 90 degrees CW to lock it in position.
Make sure the chip detector (1) is in the locked position.

l1item.para: Install the oil tank drain plug as follows:

l2item.para: Lubricate the packing726173RP03011 with ( PWC03-001)engine oil and install it on the oil tank drain plug726173PP26011 .
Lubricate the oil tank drain plug threads with ( PWC03-001)engine oil and install it on the AGB. Torque the drain plug to 40 to 50 lb.in. (4.6-5.7 Nm).

l1item.para: Do a visual inspection of the fan inlet area as follows:

l2item.para: Examine the fan case for abrasion, gouges and lifting of material.
Use your hand to make sure that the fan rotor is free to rotate.
Use (PWC34941)wrench on the starter gear to make sure the HP compressor is free to rotate.
Clean the blades of the fan rotor, and the nose cone with a soft cloth soaked in (PWC11-067)engine cleaner.

l1item.para: Do a visual inspection of the exhaust area as follows:

l2item.para: Examine the exhaust case, exhaust cowl, and exhaust end cone for distortion or buckling.
Make sure that there is no evidence of oil leaks.
Make sure that the LP turbine does not have any damage.
Make sure that there is no unwanted material inside the exhaust cowl.

l1item.para: Do an inspection of the exterior of the engine as follows:

l2item.para: Make sure that there is no damage on any parts from improper tool use.
Make sure that there is no distortion or mutilation on the engine flanges.
Make sure that there is no damage on helicoil inserts or threaded holes.
Make sure that all studs are tight and have no damage on the threads.
Make sure that there is no damage on any of the electrical connections.
Make sure that there is no damage starter pad gasket.
Examine the electrical harness and each fuel, oil, and air line or tube as follows:

l3item.para: Make sure that there are no dents, tool marks, nicks, scratches or tears.
Make sure that there is sufficient clearance from adjacent items to prevent rubbing when the engine is in operation.

l2item.para: With (PWC90012)soft jaw pliers, tightly grip the connector nut on each connector of the electrical harness, and tighten until the pliers slip.

note.para: The connector is fully coupled when the color band is covered.

caution.para: DO NOT LET ENGINE CLEANER COME INTO CONTACT WITH THE FUEL METERING UNIT.

l2item.para: Make sure that the engine is clean and has no oil on it. Clean the exterior of the engine as required with (PWC11-067)engine cleaner .
Make sure that the exterior paint has no scratches or damage. Touch up the paint as required.

l1item.para: Lubricate the coupling nut on the secondary fuel tube with (PWC03-001) engine oil. Torque the coupling nut 90 to 100 lbf.in. (10.2-11.3 Nm). With the (PWC90025) crimper and (PWC90026) test block, install the safety cable on the coupling nut (Ref. Standard Practices Manual P/N 585005, Task 70-53-00-400-102).

Lubricate the coupling nut on the primary fuel tube with (PWC03-001) engine oil. Torque the coupling nut 90 to 100 lbf.in. (10.2-11.3 Nm). With the (PWC90025) crimper and (PWC90026) test block, install safety cable on the coupling nut (Ref. Standard Practices Manual P/N 585005, Task 70-53-00-400-102).
Place the preservation tag into the appropriate size of plastic bag. Seal the bag with impulse bag sealer.
Attach the preservation tag to the primary fuel tube with a (PWC05-111) tie down strap. Make sure the preservation information is facing outwards.

l1item.para: Do a visual examination of the fan inlet area as follows:

l2item.para: Make sure the inlet area is free from foreign objects before covering.
Clean the fan blades and nose cone with a lint free cloth soaked in (PWC11-067) engine cleaner.

caution.para: DO NOT TRY TO TURN THE FAN AFTER THE LOCKING BRACKET ASSEMBLY IS INSTALLED. DAMAGE TO THE NOSE CONE CAN OCCUR.

l1item.para: Install the cone locking bracket assemblyI82NB40A111 on the nose cone. Install the four screwsI82NS02-204 , the four washersI82NW03-604 and the four nutsI82NN05-554 . Torque the four screws (DRY) 27 to 30 lbf.in. (3.1-3.4 Nm).
Install the nose cone shipping coverI82NC28-031 with the cut out at TDC on the fan case.
Install the shipping bagI82NB47-011 on the turbine exhaust case. Tighten the cable to secure the bag on the exhaust case.

graphic.title: Installation of the Fan Rotor Support Bracket and Covers

subtask.title: Installation of the Engine Identification and Reference Data Plates

l1item.para: Make sure that all the information on the data plate726193PP16011 is correct.
Lubricate the two bolts with (PWC06-004)antiseize compound . Install the data plate on the accessory gearbox with the two bolts726193AB20022 . Torque the bolts 9 to 11 lbf.in. (1.0-1.2 Nm).
Make sure that all the information on the trim data plate726193PP16021 is correct.
Lubricate the two bolts with (PWC06-004)antiseize compound . Install the trim data plate on the accessory gearbox with the two bolts726193AB20012 . Torque the bolts 9 to 11 lbf.in. (1.0-1.2 Nm).

graphic.title: Engine Identification and Reference Data Plates - Installation

subtask.title: Installation of the Lower Front Mount Bracket

l1item.para: Lubricate the four bolts with (PWC06-004)anti-seize compound . Install the lower front engine mount bracketI82NB40A041 on the left side of the engine with the four washersI82NW03-014 and four boltsI82NB20-014 . Torque the bolts 110 to 120 lbf.in. (12.4-13.5 Nm).

graphic.title: Lower Front Mount Bracket - Installation

subtask.title: Installation of the Rear Flange Bracket and Lifting Brackets

l1item.para: Lubricate the four bolts with (PWC03-001)engine oil. Install the (PWC69357)rear lifting bracket on the rear side of the bypass duct flange with the four bolts, eight washers, and nuts. Torque the nuts 36 to 40 lbf.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

Lubricate the four bolts with (PWC03-001)engine oil. Install the flange bracket I82NB40A031 on the rear side of the bypass duct flange with the four boltsI82NB20-074 , four washersI82NW03-074 , and four nutsI82NN05-074 . Torque the nuts 36 to 40 lbf.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

Lubricate the four bolts with (PWC03-001)engine oil. Install the flange bracket I82NB40A031 on the rear side of the bypass duct flange with the four boltsI82NB20-074 , four washersI82NW03-074 , and four nutsI82NN05-074 . Torque the nuts 36 to 40 lbf.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).

graphic.title: Rear Flange Bracket and Lifting Brackets - Installation

task.title: Installation of the Engine Assembly into the Shipping Container

l1item.para: Install the shipping components per 72-00-00, Storage-02, (Task 72-00-00-530-801).

warning.para: READ THE MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS BEFORE YOU USE THESE MATERIALS. SOME MATERIALS CAN BE DANGEROUS.

subtask.title: Preparation of the Shipping Container

caution.para: DO NOT USE STANDARD COMMERCIAL HARDWARE TO SECURE ENGINE SUPPORT BRACKETS TO ENGINE OR CONTAINER. USE OF HARDWARE OF LOWER STRENGTH THAN SPECIFIED COULD CAUSE SERIOUS ENGINE DAMAGE DURING SHIPPING.

l1item.para: Make sure the cradle and skid baseI82NS13-011 are serviceable and a new or serviceable fiberboard sleeveI82NS28-011 , plywood frontI82NP05-01 and coverI82NC28-011 are available.
Make sure interior of the cradle is absolutely clean and is not damaged. Vacuum and clean if necessary.

Place engine log book, log sheets and other relevant documentation to be shipped with engine, in a waterproof envelope and secure with pressure sensitive tape (PWC05-069). Place this material into a box and put in the shipping container. Secure with pressure sensitive tape.

note.para: Items should be packed with sufficient packing material to make sure items do not move during shipping.

graphic.title: Preparation of the Shipping Container

subtask.title: Installation of the Electronic Engine Control in the Shipping Container

numlitem.para: The EEC may not have been sent to the shop with the engine. If no EEC is to be returned, this procedure may be ignored.
Make sure the serial number of the EEC is the same as previously recorded when engine was received.

l1item.para: Install the four protective capsI82NC06-024 on the EEC.
Make sure the fitting is positioned as shown and install the protective capsI82NC06-031 on the EEC.
Install the EEC in the protective envelope with two desiccant bagsI82ND17-022 . Seal the EEC protective envelope with the envelope sealer.
Identify the EEC with the engine serial number.
Install the two foam insertsI82NI10-012 onto the EEC.
Install the EEC onto the container skid with the strapI82NS25-021 . Tighten the strap to hold the EEC.

note.para: Make sure the EEC label is visible.

graphic.title: Installation of the Electronic Engine Control in the Shipping Container

subtask.title: Installation of the Engine into the Shipping Container

l1item.para: Install the (PWC69262)engine sling on the engine. Remove the engine from the engine stand.

caution.para: DESICCANT BAGS ARE FRAGILE. DO NOT PLACE BAGS NEAR SHARP OBJECTS.

l1item.para: Tie eight (PWC15-001) desiccant bags equally apart along the bottom of the engine.
Carefully lower the engine onto the mount supports and install the four quick release pins. Remove the engine sling.

note.para: The rear end of the engine goes towards the wooden box.

l1item.para: Remove the (PWC69045)front engine mounts from the engine.
Remove the four bolts, the four washers, the four nuts and the lifting bracket from the front side of the bypass duct flange.

note.para: The lifting bracket is to remain with the engine sling. Install the attaching hardware on the lifting bracket. Put the lifting bracket back on the engine sling.

l1item.para: Install the rear engine mount727193PB40111 on the rear face of the bypass duct flange. Install three boltsI82NB20-043 , three washersI82NW03-043 and three nutsI82NN05-043 . Torque the nuts 36 to 40 lbf.in. (4.1-4.5 Nm).
Position the engine envelopeI82NE05-011 so that the data plates are visible and you can read the data through the envelope and the container window.
Seal the engine protective envelope with the envelope sealer.

note.para: Leave a small opening to allow for a vacuum hose.

l1item.para: Remove all the air from the engine protective envelope with a vacuum cleaner, and then seal the small opening with the envelope sealer.
Make sure that the humidity indicatorI82NI08-011 is visible through the window in the container.
Put the relevant engine shipping container instructionsI82NB48-011 in a waterproof envelopeI82NE05-011 , and attach the envelope on the outside of the sleeve of the shipping container with tape.
Place fiberboard sleeveI82NS28-011 in position on skid.
Install the coverI82NC28-011 with plywood frontI82NP05-01 on the sleeve.
Strap container to skid with three sets of 3/4 inch steel strappingI82NS25-033 and sealsI82NS06-026 . Fit twelve (12) cornersI82NC19-0212 as applicable.
Stencil engine model number, serial number, and pertinent preservation and inspection dates on both ends of the container.

graphic.title: Engine into the Shipping Container - Installation

l1item.para: For complete instructions on the engine assembly preservation schedule, refer to the applicable Maintenance Manual.
For complete instructions on the preservation of the fuel system, refer to the applicable Maintenance Manual.
For complete instructions on the preservation of the oil system, refer to the applicable Maintenance Manual.
